D: Refashioned: On Liberty - John Stuart Mill 1859 - Refashioned by ZZY
D: Original: On Liberty - John Stuart Mill 1859

D: Refashioned: This essay revisits a question that has shaped every era of human history: what are the proper limits of authority over the individual? Not free will versus determinism, but the concrete, political question of when society may legitimately constrain a person's liberty. As political structures, social dynamics, and technology evolve, these limits must be continually reassessed. The question is ancient, but modern conditions demand a fundamentally different treatment of it.
D: Original: THE SUBJECT of this Essay is not the so-called Liberty of the Will, so unfortunately opposed to the misnamed doctrine of Philosophical Necessity; but Civil, or Social Liberty: the nature and limits of the power which can be legitimately exercised by society over the individual. A question seldom stated, and hardly ever discussed, in general terms, but which profoundly influences the practical controversies of the age by its latent presence, and is likely soon to make itself recognised as the vital question of the future. It is so far from being new, that, in a certain sense, it has divided mankind, almost from the remotest ages; but in the stage of progress into which the more civilized portions of the species have now entered, it presents itself under new conditions, and requires a different and more fundamental treatment.
Refashioned Old: In this book I speak not of free will but freedom of action. Many have addressed this subject throughout history but with recent changes in power structures, social structures, and technology I want to address it in a modern context (On Libery was written in 1859)
D: Elegant: This essay is not about free will. It is about what power society may rightfully exercise over the individual. The question is as old as civilization, yet every generation must answer it anew, because the conditions under which authority operates never stop changing.
D: Summary: The essay addresses the legitimate limits of society's power over individuals, not the philosophical question of free will. Though the question is ancient, modern conditions demand it be reconsidered.
D: Distilled: Not free will, but what authority over individuals is just -- and why progress forces us to keep revisiting it.
title: On Liberty
author: JSM
Notes:
Philosophical Necessity -- Mill refers to the determinism debate (whether human actions are causally determined), which he addressed separately in A System of Logic (1843) and later in An Examination of Sir William Hamilton's Philosophy (1865). He deliberately sets this aside to focus on political liberty.

Plato's Republic (c. 375 BCE) -- The question of authority over individuals is raised by Plato, who proposed philosopher-kings and noble lies to maintain the Just City.

The framing of liberty as requiring 'different and more fundamental treatment' under modern conditions signals Mill's awareness that industrial society, mass democracy, and new communications technologies (the penny press, the telegraph) had changed the mechanisms of social control since earlier treatments by Locke, Montesquieu, and others.

D: Refashioned: Through most of recorded history, the struggle between liberty and authority -- whether in Greece, Rome, or England -- was a struggle between the governed and their rulers. Liberty meant constraining rulers who stood in natural opposition to the people: a king, a caste, or a conquering group whose authority did not rest on the consent of the governed. Their power was seen as necessary to maintain order, yet it was also dangerous -- the same force meant to preserve peace could shield corruption and suppress legitimate dissent. Limiting this power was the essence of what was called liberty, and it was pursued in two primary ways.
D: Original: The struggle between Liberty and Authority is the most conspicuous feature in the portions of history with which we are earliest familiar, particularly in that of Greece, Rome, and England. But in old times this contest was between subjects, or some classes of subjects, and the Government. By liberty, was meant protection against the tyranny of the political rulers. The rulers were conceived (except in some of the popular governments of Greece) as in a necessarily antagonistic position to the people whom they ruled. They consisted of a governing One, or a governing tribe or caste, who derived their authority from inheritance or conquest, who, at all events, did not hold it at the pleasure of the governed, and whose supremacy men did not venture, perhaps did not desire, to contest, whatever precautions might be taken against its oppressive exercise. Their power was regarded as necessary, but also as highly dangerous; as a weapon which they would attempt to use against their subjects, no less than against external enemies. To prevent the weaker members of the community from being preyed on by innumerable vultures, it was needful that there should be an animal of prey stronger than the rest, commissioned to keep them down. But as the king of the vultures would be no less bent upon preying upon the flock than any of the minor harpies, it was indispensable to be in a perpetual attitude of defence against his beak and claws. The aim, therefore, of patriots was to set limits to the power which the ruler should be suffered to exercise over the community; and this limitation was what they meant by liberty. It was attempted in two ways.
Refashioned Old: The debate and struggle between liberty and authority has shaped history, especially in Greece, Rome, and England. Rulers, who usually gaind authority from conquest or inheritance, were seen as necessary to maintain order, yet were also known to exploit their subjects. To curb this predatory power and provide structure for resistance, two core ideas emerged.
D: Elegant: The tension between liberty and authority runs through all recorded history, most visibly in Greece, Rome, and England. Authority, rooted in conquest or inheritance, was tolerated for the order it provided, even as it preyed upon the people it claimed to protect. To restrain it, two principles were forged.
D: Summary: History shows a recurring struggle between liberty and authority. Rulers were necessary for order but posed a constant threat of exploitation, so two methods emerged to check their power.
D: Distilled: Liberty began as the project of restraining rulers who were both necessary and dangerous.
Notes:
Greece, Rome, and England -- Mill selects these as the canonical examples of the liberty-authority struggle familiar to a Victorian educated audience.

Greek popular governments -- Mill's parenthetical exception refers to Athenian democracy (5th-4th century BCE), where rulers were not conceived as antagonistic to the people because citizens governed themselves directly.

The 'vulture' metaphor -- Mill's image of a stronger predator commissioned to keep down lesser ones echoes Hobbes's Leviathan (1651), where the sovereign is a necessary concentration of power to prevent the war of all against all.

Magna Carta (1215) -- The foundational English document limiting royal authority.
Hungary's Golden Bull (1222) -- A parallel European charter of noble rights.
Model Parliament (1295) -- Edward I's parliament, an early step toward representative consent.

D: Refashioned: The first method was the recognition of rights -- specific immunities that rulers were duty-bound to respect. If a ruler violated these protections, resistance or rebellion was considered justified.
D: Original: First, by obtaining a recognition of certain immunities, called political liberties or rights, which it was to be regarded as a breach of duty in the ruler to infringe, and which, if he did infringe, specific resistance, or general rebellion, was held to be justifiable.
Refashioned Old: The first method was to secure recognition of specific protections, known as political liberties or rights. If a ruler violated these, it was considered a breach of duty, and resistance, or even outright rebellion, was justified.
D: Elegant: The first safeguard: defined rights. If rulers violated them, rebellion was not treason but justice.
D: Summary: The first check on authority was establishing recognized rights whose violation justified resistance or rebellion.
D: Distilled: Rights drew a line: cross it, and resistance becomes legitimate.
Notes:
English Bill of Rights (1689) -- Established after the Glorious Revolution, codifying limits on the Crown and affirming parliamentary supremacy.

Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen (1789) -- The French revolutionary document asserting natural and civil rights.

The concept of justified rebellion echoes John Locke's Second Treatise of Government (1689), which argued that government forfeits its legitimacy when it violates the natural rights of the people.

D: Refashioned: The second method, generally later in development, was the establishment of constitutional checks: mechanisms requiring those in power to obtain the consent of the community, or its representatives, before taking significant action.
D: Original: A second, and generally a later expedient, was the establishment of constitutional checks, by which the consent of the community, or of a body of some sort, supposed to represent its interests, was made a necessary condition to some of the more important acts of the governing power.
Refashioned Old: The second, approach was to create constitutional checks. Meaning certain major decision to required the consent of the people, or at least a body meant to represent its interests.
D: Elegant: The second safeguard: constitutional checks, ensuring that major acts of power required the consent of the governed or their representatives.
D: Summary: The second check on authority was constitutional mechanisms that made major government actions contingent on community or representative approval.
D: Distilled: Constitutional checks made consent a prerequisite for the exercise of power.
Notes:
Constitutional checks -- Mill refers to the gradual development of parliamentary sovereignty, from the Magna Carta's requirement of baronial consent for taxation through the English Civil War (1642-1651) and the establishment of parliamentary supremacy after the Glorious Revolution (1688).

The distinction between rights (negative protections) and constitutional checks (procedural requirements) maps roughly onto the later legal distinction between substantive and procedural due process.

D: Refashioned: In most European countries, rulers eventually conceded certain rights but resisted constitutional checks. Securing those checks therefore became the central objective of advocates of liberty. Yet during this entire period, people accepted the basic arrangement: they were willing to be ruled by a master, so long as his power could be held within limits. Their aspirations did not yet extend beyond constraining authority -- they had not yet imagined replacing it.
D: Original: To the first of these modes of limitation, the ruling power, in most European countries, was compelled, more or less, to submit. It was not so with the second; and, to attain this, or when already in some degree possessed, to attain it more completely, became everywhere the principal object of the lovers of liberty. And so long as mankind were content to combat one enemy by another, and to be ruled by a master, on condition of being guaranteed more or less efficaciously against his tyranny, they did not carry their aspirations beyond this point.
D: Elegant: Rights were grudgingly conceded; constitutional checks had to be fought for. But the aspiration remained modest: not to abolish authority, only to cage it.
D: Summary: Rulers accepted rights more readily than constitutional checks, making the latter the primary goal of liberty advocates. People still accepted being ruled, provided authority was kept within bounds.
D: Distilled: Early liberty meant taming authority, not transcending it.
Notes:
Mill traces a progression: rights were extracted first (often through crisis or revolution), while constitutional checks -- requiring ongoing institutional mechanisms like parliaments -- took longer to establish and were more fiercely resisted because they represented a structural, permanent limitation on sovereign discretion.

The phrase 'combat one enemy by another' reflects the Hobbesian bargain: accepting a powerful sovereign to protect against worse threats, whether foreign invasion or civil disorder.

D: Refashioned:
Eventually, people stopped accepting that their rulers should be an independent, opposing force. They came to believe that officials should be chosen by the people, accountable to them, and removable at their pleasure. This demand for elected, temporary rulers became the central aim of liberal reform, gradually displacing the older project of merely limiting power.

As this ideal gained ground, a further assumption took hold: once government truly represented the people's will, further restraints on its power were unnecessary. The nation's power was the people's own power, merely concentrated into a convenient form. Why fear your own authority exercised on your own behalf? Across most of continental Europe, this view became dominant. Only a few exceptional thinkers argued that even democratic governments still needed limits.
D: Original: A time, however, came, in the progress of human affairs, when men ceased to think it a necessity of nature that their governors should be an independent power, opposed in interest to themselves. It appeared to them much better that the various magistrates of the State should be their tenants or delegates, revocable at their pleasure. In that way alone, it seemed, could they have complete security that the powers of government would never be abused to their disadvantage. By degrees this new demand for elective and temporary rulers became the prominent object of the exertions of the popular party, wherever any such party existed; and superseded, to a considerable extent, the previous efforts to limit the power of rulers. As the struggle proceeded for making the ruling power emanate from the periodical choice of the ruled, some persons began to think that too much importance had been attached to the limitation of the power itself. That (it might seem) was a resource against rulers whose interests were habitually opposed to those of the people. What was now wanted was, that the rulers should be identified with the people; that their interest and will should be the interest and will of the nation. The nation did not need to be protected against its own will. There was no fear of its tyrannizing over itself. Let the rulers be effectually responsible to it, promptly removable by it, and it could afford to trust them with power of which it could itself dictate the use to be made. Their power was but the nation’s own power, concentrated, and in a form convenient for exercise. This mode of thought, or rather perhaps of feeling, was common among the last generation of European liberalism, in the Continental section of which it still apparently predominates. Those who admit any limit to what a government may do, except in the case of such governments as they think ought not to exist, stand out as brilliant exceptions among the political thinkers of the Continent. A similar tone of sentiment might by this time have been prevalent in our own country, if the circumstances which for a time encouraged it, had continued unaltered.
D: Elegant: A new idea emerged: rulers should not be an opposing force but delegates of the people, elected and removable. And if government truly expressed the people's will, why limit it at all? The nation's power was the people's own power. Across Europe, this reasoning took hold -- and very few voices questioned it.
D: Summary: Liberal reformers shifted from limiting rulers to replacing them with elected representatives. Many then concluded that democratic government needed no further constraints, since it expressed the people's own will.
D: Distilled: Once people believed government was their own instrument, they stopped seeing any reason to restrain it.
Notes:
The 'last generation of European liberalism' -- Mill refers to the post-Napoleonic liberal movements across Europe, particularly the revolutions of 1830 and 1848, and thinkers like Benjamin Constant and Francois Guizot.

The Continental section -- Mill distinguishes between Continental liberalism (which embraced popular sovereignty with fewer reservations) and British liberalism (which retained deeper skepticism of concentrated power, shaped by the English constitutional tradition).

The idea that the people's power needs no limitation echoes Rousseau's Social Contract (1762), where the general will is by definition always right.

Mill's observation that Britain diverged reflects the influence of thinkers like Burke, who emphasized institutional checks even against democratic majorities, and the particular British experience of gradual reform rather than revolutionary rupture.

D: Refashioned:
Experience exposed the flaw in this reasoning. While democracy remained theoretical or belonged only to ancient history, it was easy to believe that self-governing people could never oppress themselves. Even the excesses of the French Revolution could be dismissed as the work of a usurping minority, not a defect of popular institutions as such. But once a democratic republic occupied a large portion of the earth and became one of the world's most powerful nations, the theory was tested against reality.

The results were sobering. 'Self-government' turned out not to mean each person governing themselves, but each being governed by all the rest. The 'will of the people' in practice meant the will of the majority -- or of those who successfully presented themselves as the majority. And that majority could desire to oppress a minority just as ruthlessly as any monarch. The need to limit government power does not diminish when power is held by elected officials accountable to the strongest faction. 'The tyranny of the majority' became a recognized danger requiring its own safeguards.
D: Original:
But, in political and philosophical theories, as well as in persons, success discloses faults and infirmities which failure might have concealed from observation. The notion, that the people have no need to limit their power over themselves, might seem axiomatic, when popular government was a thing only dreamed about, or read of as having existed at some distant period of the past. Neither was that notion necessarily disturbed by such temporary aberrations as those of the French Revolution, the worst of which were the work of an usurping few, and which, in any case, belonged, not to the permanent working of popular institutions, but to a sudden and convulsive outbreak against monarchical and aristocratic despotism. In time, however, a democratic republic came to occupy a large portion of the earth’s surface, and made itself felt as one of the most powerful members of the community of nations; and elective and responsible government became subject to the observations and criticisms which wait upon a great existing fact. It was now perceived that such phrases as “self-government,” and “the power of the people over themselves,” do not express the true state of the case. The “people” who exercise the power are not always the same people with those over whom it is exercised; and the “self-government” spoken of is not the government of each by himself, but of each by all the rest. The will of the people, moreover, practically means the will of the most numerous or the most active
part of the people; the majority, or those who succeed in making themselves accepted as the majority; the people, consequently,
may desire to oppress a part of their number; and precautions are as much needed against this as against any other abuse of power. The limitation, therefore, of the power of government over individuals loses none of its importance when the holders of power are regularly accountable to the community, that is, to the strongest party therein. This view of things, recommending itself equally to the intelligence of thinkers and to the inclination of those important classes in European society to whose real or supposed interests democracy is adverse, has had no difficulty in establishing itself; and in political speculations “the tyranny of the majority” is now generally included among the evils against which society requires to be on its guard.
D: Elegant: Success exposed what theory had concealed. 'Self-government' did not mean each person governing themselves but each being governed by all the rest. The 'will of the people' meant the will of the majority -- or those who claimed to be. And majorities can oppress minorities as effectively as any king. Democracy does not retire the need for limits on power; it proves it.
D: Summary: Once democracy moved from theory to practice, it became clear that 'the will of the people' really means the will of the majority, which can oppress minorities. Limiting government power remains essential even under democratic rule.
D: Distilled: Democracy revealed that self-government is not government of each by themselves, but of each by all the rest.
Notes:
A democratic republic came to occupy a large portion of the earth's surface -- Mill refers to the United States of America, whose rapid territorial expansion and growing global influence by the mid-19th century provided the first large-scale test of democratic governance.

Alexis de Tocqueville, Democracy in America (1835, 1840) -- Tocqueville coined the phrase 'tyranny of the majority' and provided the most influential analysis of this danger, which Mill explicitly acknowledges as a recognized concept in political thought.

The French Revolution (1789-1799) -- Mill concedes that its worst excesses (the Terror, 1793-1794) could be attributed to a usurping faction (the Jacobins under Robespierre) rather than to popular self-governance itself.

James Madison, Federalist No. 10 (1787) -- The American constitutional concern with faction and majority tyranny anticipated many of Mill's points, though Mill does not cite Madison directly.

D: Refashioned:
But government is only one channel through which collective power operates. Society itself can be the tyrant, and its methods of coercion are not limited to what it does through the state. Social pressure -- the weight of prevailing opinion, custom, and expectation -- may not carry legal penalties, but it penetrates more deeply into daily life and leaves fewer avenues of escape. It can impose conformity on those who diverge, stifling individuality before it has the chance to form, and compelling people to fashion themselves according to a single approved model.

Protecting liberty therefore requires more than constitutional limits on government. It demands a boundary on the authority of collective opinion itself. Finding that boundary, and defending it against encroachment, is as essential to human flourishing as protection against political despotism.
D: Original: Like other tyrannies, the tyranny of the majority was at first, and is still vulgarly, held in dread, chiefly as operating through the acts of the public authorities. But reflecting persons perceived that when society is itself the tyrant—society collectively, over the separate individuals who compose it—its means of tyrannizing are not restricted to the acts which it may do by the hands of its political functionaries. Society can and does execute its own mandates: and if it issues wrong mandates instead of right, or any mandates at all in things with which it ought not to meddle, it practises a social tyranny more formidable than many kinds of political oppression, since, though not usually upheld by such extreme penalties, it leaves fewer means of escape, penetrating much more deeply into the details of life, and enslaving the soul itself. Protection, therefore, against the tyranny of the magistrate is not enough: there needs protection also against the tyranny of the prevailing opinion and feeling; against the tendency of society to impose, by other means than civil penalties, its own ideas and practices as rules of conduct on those who dissent from them; to fetter the development, and, if possible, prevent the formation, of any individuality not in harmony with its ways, and compel all characters to fashion themselves upon the model of its own. There is a limit to the legitimate interference of collective opinion with individual independence: and to find that limit, and maintain it against encroachment, is as indispensable to a good condition of human affairs, as protection against political despotism.
D: Elegant: The majority does not tyrannize only through law. Social pressure penetrates deeper than any statute, enforcing conformity not by punishment but by suffocation. It leaves fewer means of escape and can crush individuality before it forms. Liberty requires protection not only against the state, but against the despotism of prevailing opinion.
D: Summary: Society exerts tyranny not just through government but through social pressure, which penetrates more deeply into life and is harder to escape. Liberty requires limits on collective opinion, not just on political power.
D: Distilled: Social pressure is more insidious than law: it does not punish dissent so much as prevent it from forming.
Notes:
Mill's distinction between political tyranny and social tyranny is one of his most original contributions. While Tocqueville had identified the 'tyranny of the majority' primarily in political terms, Mill extends it to the informal mechanisms of social coercion -- what he elsewhere calls 'the tyranny of prevailing opinion and feeling.'

'Enslaving the soul itself' -- Mill's language echoes concerns about conformity that would later be developed by thinkers like Kierkegaard (The Present Age, 1846), Nietzsche, and in the 20th century by Erich Fromm (Escape from Freedom, 1941) and Hannah Arendt.

The idea that social tyranny can 'prevent the formation of any individuality' anticipates Michel Foucault's later analysis of disciplinary power and normalization (Discipline and Punish, 1975).

D: Refashioned:
Yet everything that makes life valuable depends on some restraint of individual conduct. Rules must exist -- enforced by law where appropriate, and by social opinion where law is unsuitable. The real question is what those rules should be, and it is one of the least settled questions in human affairs. Beyond a few obvious cases, almost no consensus exists. No two eras, and scarcely any two countries, have drawn this boundary in the same place, and each is astonished by the judgments of the other.

This is the foundational problem: how should society determine the proper limits between individual freedom and collective control?
D: Original: But though this proposition is not likely to be contested in general terms, the practical question, where to place the limit—how to make the fitting adjustment between individual independence and social control—is a subject on which nearly everything remains to be done. All that makes existence valuable to any one, depends on the enforcement of restraints upon the actions of other people. Some rules of conduct, therefore, must be imposed, by law in the first place, and by opinion on many things which are not fit subjects for the operation of law. What these rules should be, is the principal question in human affairs; but if we except a few of the most obvious cases, it is one of those which least progress has been made in resolving. No two ages, and scarcely any two countries, have decided it alike; and the decision of one age or country is a wonder to another.
D: Elegant: Life requires rules -- some enforced by law, others by social pressure. But which rules, and where the line falls between freedom and control, is one of the least resolved questions in human history. No two ages or nations have answered it alike, and each finds the other's answer bewildering.
D: Summary: Some restraints on conduct are necessary for society to function, but humanity has made almost no progress in determining which restraints are legitimate. The boundary between freedom and control varies wildly across time and place.
D: Distilled: Everyone agrees that some rules are necessary; almost no one agrees on which ones.
Notes:
Mill's claim that 'least progress has been made' in resolving the question of legitimate social rules echoes his broader philosophy of progress. In A System of Logic (1843) and elsewhere, he argued that the moral sciences lagged far behind the natural sciences in establishing reliable principles.

The observation that different ages and countries reach contradictory conclusions on moral regulation reflects the influence of comparative and historical approaches to ethics that emerged in the 18th and 19th centuries, particularly through Montesquieu's The Spirit of the Laws (1748), which showed how laws and customs varied with climate, culture, and political structure.

D: Refashioned: Yet people rarely notice how unsettled the question is. The norms of any given era feel obvious and self-justifying, as though they expressed some natural truth about how life should be lived. This is the power of custom: it becomes so deeply ingrained that people mistake it for human nature itself, and the possibility of questioning it barely arises. Because these social rules feel unquestionable, people seldom think they need reasons for them -- either when explaining them to others or when examining their own beliefs. Many come to believe, often with encouragement from those who claim authority, that their feelings on such matters are better than reasons and make reasons unnecessary.
D: Original: Yet the people of any given age and country no more suspect any difficulty in it, than if it were a subject on which mankind had always been agreed. The rules which obtain among themselves appear to them self-evident and self-justifying. This all but universal illusion is one of the examples of the magical influence of custom, which is not only, as the proverb says, a second nature, but is continually mistaken for the first. The effect of custom, in preventing any misgiving respecting the rules of conduct which mankind impose on one another, is all the more complete because the subject is one on which it is not generally considered necessary that reasons should be given, either by one person to others, or by each to himself. People are accustomed to believe, and have been encouraged in the belief by some who aspire to the character of philosophers, that their feelings, on subjects of this nature, are better than reasons, and render reasons unnecessary.
D: Elegant: Custom is so powerful that people mistake it for nature. The norms of every era feel self-evident to those living under them, and questioning them rarely occurs to anyone. When feeling is treated as superior to reason, the demand for justification disappears entirely.
D: Summary: People treat the norms of their own time as self-evident truths rather than customs. Because these norms feel natural, people rarely seek or offer reasons for them, relying on feeling instead.
D: Distilled: Custom masquerades as nature, and feeling displaces reason, so the norms of every era escape examination.
Notes:
Mill's argument about custom being mistaken for nature draws on a long philosophical tradition. Montaigne's Essays (1580) argued that 'the principal effect of custom is to seize and ensnare us.' Pascal made a similar point: 'Custom is our nature' (Pensees, 1670).

'Some who aspire to the character of philosophers' -- Mill likely refers to intuitionist moral philosophers, particularly William Whewell, whose moral philosophy (Elements of Morality, 1845) held that moral truths are self-evident and apprehended by a moral sense rather than derived from reason or utility. Mill explicitly attacked Whewell's intuitionism in his essay on Whewell (1852).

The broader target is the 'moral sense' tradition from Shaftesbury and Hutcheson through the Scottish Enlightenment, which held that moral judgments are delivered by an innate faculty rather than by rational deliberation.

D: Refashioned:
In practice, what guides most people's views on how others should behave is simply the feeling that everyone should act as they and their allies would prefer. No one admits that their standard of judgment is merely personal preference. But an opinion on conduct that rests on no reasons beyond that preference is exactly that -- one person's liking. And when reasons are offered, they usually amount to an appeal to the same preference felt by others, which makes it many people's liking rather than one person's, but no more principled.

For most people, this shared preference is the only basis they have for judging what is admirable or blameworthy, outside of whatever their religious creed explicitly prescribes. And even their interpretation of that creed is usually shaped by the same unexamined feelings.
D: Original: The practical principle which guides them to their opinions on the regulation of human conduct, is the feeling in each person’s mind that everybody should be required to act as he, and those with whom he sympathizes, would like them to act. No one, indeed, acknowledges to himself that his standard of judgment is his own liking; but an opinion on a point of conduct, not supported by reasons, can only count as one person’s preference; and if the reasons, when given, are a mere appeal to a similar preference felt by other people, it is still only many people’s liking instead of one. To an ordinary man, however, his own preference, thus supported, is not only a perfectly satisfactory reason, but the only one he generally has for any of his notions of morality, taste, or propriety, which are not expressly written in his religious creed; and his chief guide in the interpretation even of that. Men’s opinions, accordingly, on what is laudable or blameable, are affected by all the multifarious causes which influence their wishes in regard to the conduct of others, and which are as numerous as those which determine their wishes on any other subject.
D: Elegant: Most moral judgment reduces to this: everyone should act the way I want them to. No one admits this, but an opinion unsupported by reasons is just a preference -- and a preference shared by millions is still a preference, not a principle.
D: Summary: People's moral judgments typically rest on personal preference rather than reasoned principles. Even when shared widely, preferences remain preferences. Religious doctrine is usually interpreted through the same unexamined feelings.
D: Distilled: A preference held by a million people is still a preference, not a principle.
Notes:
Mill's reduction of unreasoned moral opinion to 'liking' connects to his broader utilitarian project of grounding ethics in demonstrable consequences rather than intuition or sentiment.

The critique of treating shared sentiment as moral authority challenges Hume's observation that morality is 'more properly felt than judged of' (A Treatise of Human Nature, 1739). Mill agrees with Hume that people do in fact rely on feeling, but unlike Hume, he sees this as a problem to be corrected rather than a feature of moral psychology to be accepted.

Mill's point about religious interpretation being shaped by prior preferences anticipates the hermeneutic circle -- the idea that interpreters bring preexisting assumptions to any text, including scripture.

D: Refashioned: The forces shaping these preferences are various and unreliable: sometimes reason, but more often prejudice, superstition, envy, arrogance, fear, or self-interest. Wherever a dominant class exists, a large portion of the prevailing morality reflects its interests and its sense of superiority. The moral codes governing relations between Spartans and Helots, planters and enslaved people, nobles and commoners, men and women -- all were shaped primarily by the interests of the powerful class. These class-generated sentiments then reinforced themselves, becoming the moral feelings that members of the dominant group applied even among themselves. When a formerly dominant class loses its position, the prevailing moral sentiments often swing to the opposite extreme, expressing resentment of hierarchy rather than any principled reconsideration.
D: Original: Sometimes their reason—at other times their prejudices or superstitions: often their social affections, not seldom their antisocial ones, their envy or jealousy, their arrogance or contemptuousness: but most commonly, their desires or fears for themselves—their legitimate or illegitimate self-interest. Wherever there is an ascendant class, a large portion of the morality of the country emanates from its class interests, and its feelings of class superiority. The morality between Spartans and Helots, between planters and negroes, between princes and subjects, between nobles and roturiers, between men and women, has been for the most part the creation of these class interests and feelings: and the sentiments thus generated, react in turn upon the moral feelings of the members of the ascendant class, in their relations among themselves. Where, on the other hand, a class, formerly ascendant, has lost its ascendancy, or where its ascendancy is unpopular, the prevailing moral sentiments frequently bear the impress of an impatient dislike of superiority.
D: Elegant: Morality is shaped less by reason than by prejudice, self-interest, and class power. Wherever one group dominates another -- masters over slaves, men over women, nobles over commoners -- the ruling morality reflects the rulers' interests. And when hierarchies collapse, resentment replaces principle, not justice.
D: Summary: Prevailing moral rules are typically shaped by prejudice, self-interest, and the interests of dominant classes rather than by reason. When power shifts, moral norms often reverse direction without becoming more principled.
D: Distilled: Most of what societies call morality is class interest dressed in the language of virtue.
Notes:
Spartans and Helots -- The Helots were a subjugated population in ancient Sparta (c. 7th century BCE onward), essentially state-owned serfs. Spartan morality sanctioned extreme violence against them, including ritual declarations of war that made killing Helots legally permissible.

Planters and negroes -- Mill refers to chattel slavery in the Americas. The Slavery Abolition Act (1833) had ended slavery in the British Empire, but American slavery persisted until the 13th Amendment (1865), six years after On Liberty was published.

Nobles and roturiers -- 'Roturiers' refers to non-noble commoners in the French feudal system.

Mill's analysis of morality as a product of class interest anticipates Marx and Engels's argument in The German Ideology (1846) and The Communist Manifesto (1848) that 'the ruling ideas of each age have ever been the ideas of its ruling class.' Mill was aware of socialist thought but arrived at this observation from a liberal rather than a materialist framework.

D: Refashioned:
Another powerful source of moral customs has been deference to authority -- whether temporal rulers or gods. This servility is not hypocrisy; it produces genuine feelings of moral revulsion. It led communities to burn alleged witches and execute heretics with sincere conviction.

The genuine interests of society have, of course, also played a role in shaping moral sentiment -- but less through rational consideration than through the sympathies and hostilities those interests generated. And sentiments with little connection to society's real interests have shaped moral rules with equal force.
D: Original: Another grand determining principle of the rules of conduct, both in act and forbearance, which have been enforced by law or opinion, has been the servility of mankind towards the supposed preferences or aversions of their temporal masters, or of their gods. This servility, though essentially selfish, is not hypocrisy; it gives rise to perfectly genuine sentiments of abhorrence; it made men burn magicians and heretics. Among so many baser influences, the general and obvious interests of society have of course had a share, and a large one, in the direction of the moral sentiments: less, however, as a matter of reason, and on their own account, than as a consequence of the sympathies and antipathies which grew out of them: and sympathies and antipathies which had little or nothing to do with the interests of society, have made themselves felt in the establishment of moralities with quite as great force.
D: Elegant: Deference to earthly and divine authority has shaped morality as powerfully as class interest. This servility is not cynical -- it generates sincere moral feeling. It made people burn witches and heretics in good conscience. The real interests of society have influenced morality too, but less through reason than through the passions those interests aroused.
D: Summary: Deference to rulers and religious authority has been a major source of moral rules, producing genuine but often destructive convictions. Society's actual interests have shaped morality less through reason than through the emotions they generate.
D: Distilled: Obedience to authority produces genuine moral feeling -- which is precisely what makes it dangerous.
Notes:
Burning magicians and heretics -- Mill references the European witch trials (c. 15th-18th centuries), which resulted in an estimated 40,000-60,000 executions, and the Inquisition's prosecution of heresy. The Spanish Inquisition (established 1478) and the burning of figures like Giordano Bruno (1600) and the persecution of Galileo (1633) are representative examples.

Odium theologicum -- Mill uses this Latin phrase (theological hatred) later in the chapter. It refers to the peculiar intensity of hostility generated by religious disagreement.

The distinction between morality arising from society's genuine interests versus from 'sympathies and antipathies which had little or nothing to do with the interests of society' is central to Mill's utilitarian critique. He argues that moral rules should be grounded in demonstrable consequences for human welfare, not in inherited emotional reactions.

D: Refashioned:
The preferences and aversions of society -- or its most powerful faction -- have thus been the primary force determining what rules are imposed on everyone. Even forward-thinking reformers have rarely challenged the deeper assumption that collective feeling should govern individual conduct. Instead of defending a general right to differ, they have focused on persuading society to adjust the specific customs they personally oppose. They seek to refine particular norms, not to question whether social feeling should function as law over individuals at all.

Religion is the one major exception. Only in matters of faith have people defended, on principle, the individual's right to dissent from the majority. And this defense emerged not from philosophical conviction but from practical necessity: after prolonged conflict among sects, none achieved dominance, and minorities with no prospect of becoming majorities were forced to argue for the freedom to differ. The great advocates of religious liberty asserted freedom of conscience as an absolute right and denied that anyone is accountable to others for their beliefs.

Yet even this hard-won tolerance remains fragile. Genuine religious freedom has been realized in practice mainly where religious indifference keeps the peace, not where deep conviction prevails. In the minds of most religious people, even in tolerant countries, acceptance of dissent comes with tacit limits. One person tolerates disagreement on church governance but not doctrine; another accepts everyone except Catholics or atheists; another draws the line at belief in God. Wherever the majority's conviction remains intense, its expectation of obedience scarcely diminishes.
D: Original:
The likings and dislikings of society, or of some powerful portion of it, are thus the main thing which has practically determined the rules laid down for general observance, under the penalties of law or opinion. And in general, those who have been in advance of society in thought and feeling, have left this condition of things unassailed in principle, however they may have come into conflict with it in some of its details. They have occupied themselves rather in inquiring what things society ought to like or dislike, than in questioning whether its likings or dislikings should be a law to individuals. They preferred endeavouring to alter the feelings of mankind on the particular points on which they were themselves heretical, rather than make common cause in defence of freedom, with heretics generally. The only case in which the higher ground has been taken on principle and maintained with consistency, by any but an individual here and there, is that of religious belief: a case instructive in many ways, and not least so as forming a most striking instance of the fallibility of what is called the moral sense: for the
odium theologicum, in a sincere bigot, is one of the most unequivocal cases of moral feeling. Those who first broke the yoke of what called itself the Universal Church, were in general as little willing to permit difference of religious opinion as that church itself. But when the heat of the conflict was over, without giving a complete victory to any party, and each church or sect was reduced to limit its hopes to retaining possession of the ground it already occupied; minorities, seeing that they had no chance of becoming majorities, were under the necessity of pleading to those whom they could not convert, for permission to differ. It is accordingly on this battle field, almost solely, that the rights of the individual against society have been asserted on broad grounds of principle, and the claim of society to exercise authority over dissentients, openly controverted. The great writers to whom the world owes what religious liberty it possesses, have mostly asserted freedom of conscience as an indefeasible right, and denied absolutely that a human being is accountable to others for his religious belief. Yet so natural to mankind is intolerance in whatever they really care about, that religious freedom has hardly anywhere been practically realized, except where religious indifference, which dislikes to have its peace disturbed by theological quarrels, has added its weight to the scale. In the minds of almost all religious persons, even in the most tolerant countries, the duty of toleration is admitted with tacit reserves. One person will bear with dissent in matters of church government, but not of dogma; another can tolerate everybody, short of a Papist or an Unitarian; another, every one who believes in revealed religion; a few extend their charity a little further, but stop at the belief in a God and in a future state. Wherever the sentiment of the majority is still genuine and intense, it is found to have abated little of its claim to be obeyed.
D: Elegant: Even progressive reformers rarely challenge the assumption that collective feeling should rule individual conduct. They try to change which feelings prevail, not whether feelings should govern at all. Religion alone forced the question of principle -- and only because no sect could achieve total victory. Minorities argued for tolerance out of necessity, not philosophy. Yet even religious freedom has been fully realized only where indifference, not conviction, keeps the peace. Wherever belief runs deep, tolerance runs shallow.
D: Summary: Reformers typically try to change society's specific preferences rather than questioning whether collective feeling should govern individuals at all. Religious liberty is the one area where the right to dissent has been defended on principle, but only because sectarian stalemate forced it. Even so, genuine tolerance remains rare where strong conviction exists.
D: Distilled: Tolerance has been won not by principle but by stalemate -- and it lasts only as long as no faction feels strong enough to impose its will.
Notes:
The great writers to whom the world owes what religious liberty it possesses -- Mill likely has in mind John Locke (A Letter Concerning Toleration, 1689), Pierre Bayle (Philosophical Commentary, 1686), and Voltaire (Treatise on Tolerance, 1763).

The Universal Church -- The Roman Catholic Church before the Reformation. The Protestant Reformation, initiated by Martin Luther (1517), broke its monopoly on Western Christianity.

Mill's observation that Protestant reformers 'were in general as little willing to permit difference of religious opinion as that church itself' references figures like John Calvin, whose theocratic governance of Geneva included the execution of Michael Servetus for heresy (1553).

Papist or Unitarian -- Catholics ('Papists') were subject to legal disabilities in England until Catholic Emancipation (1829). Unitarians, who denied the Trinity, were excluded from the Toleration Act of 1689 and faced legal penalties until 1813.

Odium theologicum -- Latin: theological hatred. The intense hostility generated by religious disagreement, which Mill calls 'one of the most unequivocal cases of moral feeling,' illustrating how sincere moral conviction can produce persecution.

D: Refashioned:
In practice, no society has developed a clear, consistent principle for deciding when government should intervene in individual conduct. People resist or welcome interference based on habit, temperament, or personal interest -- not on any reasoned standard. Some call for government action whenever they see a social problem to be solved. Others would rather endure significant harm than expand the reach of state authority. In each case, the position depends less on principle than on sentiment, convenience, or trust in how the government would act.

England illustrates this confusion. Legal interference with private conduct has historically been lighter there than in most of Europe -- but not because of any principled commitment to individual independence. Rather, the English have retained an older habit of viewing government as an opposing interest, a holdover from the era before democratic accountability. This instinct, though often salutary, is applied with little discrimination: it resists government control as reflexively in areas where regulation is warranted as in areas where it is not.

Because no shared principle guides these judgments, government interference is as often demanded where it is unwarranted as condemned where it is justified.
D: Original: In England, from the peculiar circumstances of our political history, though the yoke of opinion is perhaps heavier, that of law is lighter, than in most other countries of Europe; and there is considerable jealousy of direct interference, by the legislative or the executive power, with private conduct; not so much from any just regard for the independence of the individual, as from the still subsisting habit of looking on the government as representing an opposite interest to the public. The majority have not yet learnt to feel the power of the government their power, or its opinions their opinions. When they do so, individual liberty will probably be as much exposed to invasion from the government, as it already is from public opinion. But, as yet, there is a considerable amount of feeling ready to be called forth against any attempt of the law to control individuals in things in which they have not hitherto been accustomed to be controlled by it; and this with very little discrimination as to whether the matter is, or is not, within the legitimate sphere of legal control; insomuch that the feeling, highly salutary on the whole, is perhaps quite as often misplaced as well grounded in the particular instances of its application. There is, in fact, no recognised principle by which the propriety or impropriety of government interference is customarily tested. People decide according to their personal preferences. Some, whenever they see any good to be done, or evil to be remedied, would willingly instigate the government to undertake the business; while others prefer to bear almost any amount of social evil, rather than add one to the departments of human interests amenable to governmental control. And men range themselves on one or the other side in any particular case, according to this general direction of their sentiments; or according to the degree of interest which they feel in the particular thing which it is proposed that the government should do, or according to the belief they entertain that the government would, or would not, do it in the manner they prefer; but very rarely on account of any opinion to which they consistently adhere, as to what things are fit to be done by a government. And it seems to me that in consequence of this absence of rule or principle, one side is at present as often wrong as the other; the interference of government is, with about equal frequency, improperly invoked and improperly condemned.
D: Elegant: No society has a principled standard for when government should intervene. People invoke or resist state power based on habit and sentiment, not reason. Some want government to solve every problem; others would endure any evil rather than expand its reach. Without a guiding principle, interference is as often wrong when demanded as when refused.
D: Summary: Societies lack a consistent principle for determining when government intervention is justified. People's positions depend on habit, temperament, and self-interest rather than reasoned standards, leading to intervention being both wrongly demanded and wrongly refused with equal frequency.
D: Distilled: Without a principle to guide it, every call for government action and every resistance to it is equally arbitrary.
Notes:
Mill's description of England's lighter legal interference reflects the common-law tradition's emphasis on individual rights and its historical suspicion of continental-style administrative regulation.

The English habit of viewing government as 'representing an opposite interest to the public' is a legacy of the long constitutional struggle between Crown and Parliament, from the Magna Carta through the English Civil War (1642-1651) and the Glorious Revolution (1688).

Mill's warning that 'when they do so' -- when the majority learns to feel the government's power as their own -- 'individual liberty will probably be as much exposed to invasion from the government, as it already is from public opinion' is a predictive argument about the trajectory of democratic governance.

The passage implicitly critiques both laissez-faire liberalism (which resists all intervention) and what Mill elsewhere calls 'paternal government' (which intervenes paternalistically), arguing that both positions are adopted without principled foundation.

D: Refashioned:
The purpose of this essay is to defend one principle that should govern every exercise of authority over the individual, whether that authority takes the form of legal penalties, physical force, or social pressure.

The principle is this: the only legitimate reason to interfere with any person's liberty is to prevent harm to others.

A person's own good -- physical, moral, or spiritual -- is never a sufficient justification for coercion. No one may be compelled to act, or prevented from acting, because others believe it would benefit them, make them happier, or be wiser or more virtuous. Such considerations are excellent reasons to advise, persuade, or appeal -- but never to compel. Coercion is justified only when the conduct in question threatens genuine harm to someone other than the person acting.

The individual is accountable to society only for actions that affect others. In everything that concerns only themselves, their freedom is absolute. Over their own body and mind, each person is sovereign.
D: Original: The object of this Essay is to assert one very simple principle, as entitled to govern absolutely the dealings of society with the individual in the way of compulsion and control, whether the means used be physical force in the form of legal penalties, or the moral coercion of public opinion. That principle is, that the sole end for which mankind are warranted, individually or collectively, in interfering with the liberty of action of any of their number, is self-protection. That the only purpose for which power can be rightfully exercised over any member of a civilized community, against his will, is to prevent harm to others. His own good, either physical or moral, is not a sufficient warrant. He cannot rightfully be compelled to do or forbear because it will be better for him to do so, because it will make him happier, because, in the opinions of others, to do so would be wise, or even right. These are good reasons for remonstrating with him, or reasoning with him, or persuading him, or entreating him, but not for compelling him, or visiting him with any evil in case he do otherwise. To justify that, the conduct from which it is desired to deter him, must be calculated to produce evil to some one else. The only part of the conduct of any one, for which he is amenable to society, is that which concerns others. In the part which merely concerns himself, his independence is, of right, absolute. Over himself, over his own body and mind, the individual is sovereign.
D: Elegant: One principle should govern all authority over the individual: power may be exercised over a person, against their will, only to prevent harm to others. Not for their own good. Not because others think them foolish or wrong. You may advise, persuade, implore -- but you may not compel. Over their own body and mind, each person is sovereign.
D: Summary: The essay's central principle: individual liberty may be restricted only to prevent harm to others. A person's own good is never sufficient reason for coercion. In matters concerning only themselves, the individual is sovereign.
D: Distilled: The only legitimate reason to restrict anyone's freedom is to prevent harm to others -- never for their own good.
Notes:
This passage states what has come to be known as the Harm Principle, Mill's most influential contribution to political philosophy.

The distinction between legitimate persuasion and illegitimate compulsion is central to Mill's liberalism. It draws a line between social influence (acceptable) and social coercion (requiring justification).

'Over himself, over his own body and mind, the individual is sovereign' -- This claim of individual sovereignty has been invoked in countless legal and philosophical contexts, from arguments for bodily autonomy and reproductive rights to drug decriminalization and the right to die.

Mill's principle builds on but goes beyond earlier liberal thinkers. Locke grounded rights in natural law; Mill grounds them in utility -- specifically, in the long-term interests of humanity as 'progressive beings' (which he will elaborate shortly).

The phrase 'self-regarding conduct' (conduct concerning only oneself) became a term of art in political philosophy. The question of whether truly self-regarding conduct exists -- whether any action affects only the actor -- has been the most persistent objection to Mill's principle.

D: Refashioned:
This principle applies only to adults in full possession of their faculties. Children, and those not yet capable of directing their own lives, must be protected not only from external harm but from the consequences of their own actions.

The same exception applies to societies in an early stage of development. Where the obstacles to progress are immense and self-directed improvement not yet possible, rulers may be justified in using extraordinary means to achieve otherwise unattainable ends. In such conditions, a benevolent despotism can be legitimate -- if its genuine purpose is the improvement of the population and its methods actually achieve that aim. Liberty as a governing principle becomes relevant only once people have developed the capacity to benefit from free and equal discussion.

But once a society has reached that stage -- a condition long since achieved in all the communities this essay addresses -- compulsion can no longer be justified for a person's own good. Interference is warranted only to protect others from harm.
D: Original: It is, perhaps, hardly necessary to say that this doctrine is meant to apply only to human beings in the maturity of their faculties. We are not speaking of children, or of young persons below the age which the law may fix as that of manhood or womanhood. Those who are still in a state to require being taken care of by others, must be protected against their own actions as well as against external injury. For the same reason, we may leave out of consideration those backward states of society in which the race itself may be considered as in its nonage. The early difficulties in the way of spontaneous progress are so great, that there is seldom any choice of means for overcoming them; and a ruler full of the spirit of improvement is warranted in the use of any expedients that will attain an end, perhaps otherwise unattainable. Despotism is a legitimate mode of government in dealing with barbarians, provided the end be their improvement, and the means justified by actually effecting that end. Liberty, as a principle, has no application to any state of things anterior to the time when mankind have become capable of being improved by free and equal discussion. Until then, there is nothing for them but implicit obedience to an Akbar or a Charlemagne, if they are so fortunate as to find one. But as soon as mankind have attained the capacity of being guided to their own improvement by conviction or persuasion (a period long since reached in all nations with whom we need here concern ourselves), compulsion, either in the direct form or in that of pains and penalties for non-compliance, is no longer admissible as a means to their own good, and justifiable only for the security of others.
D: Elegant: This principle applies only to capable adults, not to children or to societies too early in development for free discussion to be effective. In such cases, benevolent authority may be justified. But once a people can reason and persuade, compulsion for their own good loses all legitimacy. Only the protection of others warrants it.
D: Summary: The harm principle applies only to mature adults and developed societies. Children, dependents, and societies not yet capable of benefiting from free discussion may require paternalistic authority. Once that capacity exists, compulsion is justified only to prevent harm to others.
D: Distilled: Liberty as a principle applies only where people are capable of being improved by discussion rather than by command.
Notes:
Akbar (1542-1605) -- Mughal Emperor of India, known for religious tolerance and administrative reform. Mill cites him as an example of a benevolent despot who advanced his people's development.

Charlemagne (742-814) -- King of the Franks and first Holy Roman Emperor, who unified much of Western Europe and promoted education and cultural revival (the Carolingian Renaissance).

Mill's argument that 'despotism is a legitimate mode of government in dealing with barbarians' has been his most criticized claim. Postcolonial scholars, notably Edward Said (Orientalism, 1978), have identified this passage as providing intellectual justification for European colonialism. Mill himself worked for the British East India Company for 35 years (1823-1858), and his views on colonial governance were shaped by that experience.

The concept of 'nonage' (minority, immaturity) echoes Kant's famous definition of Enlightenment as 'the exit of man from his self-incurred nonage' (What Is Enlightenment?, 1784), though Mill applies it to entire societies rather than to individuals.

The criterion of being 'capable of being improved by free and equal discussion' sets a threshold for when liberal principles apply -- a threshold Mill believes all 'civilized' nations have passed.

D: Refashioned:
I do not ground this argument in abstract natural rights, independent of consequences. Utility is the ultimate standard in all ethical questions -- but utility understood in the broadest sense: the long-term interests of human beings as progressive, developing creatures.

Those interests authorize restricting individual freedom only where a person's actions affect others. When someone causes harm to others, there is a clear case for accountability -- through law, or where law is unsuitable, through social disapproval. Certain positive obligations may also be rightfully enforced: giving testimony in court, contributing to common defense, and performing obvious duties of rescue, such as saving a life when doing so is clearly possible.

A person may cause harm through inaction as well as action, and in either case may be held accountable. But compulsion for failure to act requires far greater caution. Holding someone responsible for causing harm is the rule; holding them responsible for failing to prevent it is the exception -- though at times a necessary one.

Where enforcement would do more harm than good, or where an individual is likely to act better when left to their own judgment, society may rightly refrain from imposing accountability. But these are practical considerations, not denials of society's authority. And where external accountability cannot apply, the individual's own conscience must fill the role -- judging more strictly precisely because no public judgment is possible.
D: Original:
It is proper to state that I forego any advantage which could be derived to my argument from the idea of abstract right, as a thing independent of utility. I regard utility as the ultimate appeal on all ethical questions; but it must be utility in the largest sense, grounded on the permanent interests of man as a progressive being. Those interests, I contend, authorize the subjection of individual spontaneity to external control, only in respect to those actions of each, which concern the interest of other people. If any one does an act hurtful to others, there is a
primâ facie case for punishing him, by law, or, where legal penalties are not safely applicable, by general disapprobation. There are also many positive acts for the benefit of others, which he may rightfully be compelled to perform; such as, to give evidence in a court of justice; to bear his fair share in the common defence, or in any other joint work necessary to the interest of the society of which he enjoys the protection; and to perform certain acts of individual beneficence, such as saving a fellow-creature’s life, or interposing to protect the defenceless against ill-usage, things which whenever it is obviously a man’s duty to do, he may rightfully be made responsible to society for not doing. A person may cause evil to others not only by his actions but by his inaction, and in either case he is justly accountable to them for the injury. The latter case, it is true, requires a much more cautious exercise of compulsion than the former. To make any one answerable for doing evil to others, is the rule; to make him answerable for not preventing evil, is, comparatively speaking, the exception. Yet there are many cases clear enough and grave enough to justify that exception. In all things which regard the external relations of the individual, he is
de jure amenable to those whose interests are concerned, and if need be, to society as their protector. There are often good reasons for not holding him to the responsibility; but these reasons must arise from the special expediencies of the case: either because it is a kind of case in which he is on the whole likely to act better, when left to his own discretion, than when controlled in any way in which society have it in their power to control him; or because the attempt to exercise control would produce other evils, greater than those which it would prevent. When such reasons as these preclude the enforcement of responsibility, the conscience of the agent himself should step into the vacant judgment seat, and protect those interests of others which have no external protection; judging himself all the more rigidly, because the case does not admit of his being made accountable to the judgment of his fellow-creatures.
D: Elegant: I claim no abstract natural rights. Utility is the final standard -- but utility in the deepest sense: the permanent interests of humanity as progressive beings. Those interests justify restricting liberty only to prevent harm to others. Harm through inaction can also warrant accountability, though with greater caution. Where society cannot enforce responsibility, conscience must, and should judge more strictly for the absence of external check.
D: Summary: Mill grounds his argument in utility, not natural rights -- but utility understood as humanity's long-term developmental interests. These justify restricting freedom only where actions affect others. Accountability for inaction is sometimes warranted but requires greater caution. Where enforcement is impractical, individual conscience must substitute.
D: Distilled: Utility, not abstract rights, justifies the harm principle -- and utility means the permanent interests of humanity as progressive beings.
Notes:
Mill's explicit rejection of 'abstract right, as a thing independent of utility' distances him from the natural-rights tradition of Locke and from the Rights of Man tradition of Thomas Paine (1791). It also distinguishes his position from Kant's deontological ethics, which grounds rights in pure practical reason rather than consequences.

'Utility in the largest sense, grounded on the permanent interests of man as a progressive being' -- This is Mill's most important qualification of utilitarianism. It is not about maximizing momentary pleasure but about protecting the conditions under which human beings develop their capacities over time. This connects to his arguments in Utilitarianism (1863) about higher and lower pleasures.

Prima facie -- Latin: at first appearance. A legal term meaning 'sufficient to establish a fact unless rebutted.'

De jure -- Latin: by right, according to law.

The positive obligations Mill lists (testimony, common defense, rescue) represent limits to the libertarian reading of his harm principle. He explicitly affirms that liberty does not mean freedom from all obligation -- only from obligations that serve no one's interests but the individual's own.

The passage about conscience substituting for external accountability reflects Mill's broader moral psychology: the internalized 'sanction' of conscience is, in his utilitarian framework, a feeling of guilt or duty that has been cultivated through education and experience.

D: Refashioned:
There is, however, a sphere of life in which society has at most an indirect interest: everything a person does that affects only themselves, or affects others only with their free, informed, and voluntary consent.

This is the proper domain of individual liberty, and it comprises three elements.

First, freedom of thought and conscience in the fullest sense: the liberty to hold any opinion or belief on any subject -- practical, scientific, moral, or theological. Inseparable from this is freedom of expression. Though speech and publication involve others, the liberty to voice and share one's views is so closely linked to the liberty to hold them that the two stand or fall together.

Second, freedom of tastes and pursuits: the liberty to shape one's own life according to one's own character, to do as one judges best, so long as no one else is harmed -- even when others consider one's choices foolish, perverse, or wrong.

Third, the freedom to associate. If individuals are free to think and to live as they choose, it follows that they are free to combine with others for any purpose that does not harm those outside the association, provided all participants act willingly and without deception.
D: Original: But there is a sphere of action in which society, as distinguished from the individual, has, if any, only an indirect interest; comprehending all that portion of a person’s life and conduct which affects only himself, or if it also affects others, only with their free, voluntary, and undeceived consent and participation. When I say only himself, I mean directly, and in the first instance: for whatever affects himself, may affect others through himself; and the objection which may be grounded on this contingency, will receive consideration in the sequel. This, then, is the appropriate region of human liberty. It comprises, first, the inward domain of consciousness; demanding liberty of conscience, in the most comprehensive sense; liberty of thought and feeling; absolute freedom of opinion and sentiment on all subjects, practical or speculative, scientific, moral, or theological. The liberty of expressing and publishing opinions may seem to fall under a different principle, since it belongs to that part of the conduct of an individual which concerns other people; but, being almost of as much importance as the liberty of thought itself, and resting in great part on the same reasons, is practically inseparable from it. Secondly, the principle requires liberty of tastes and pursuits; of framing the plan of our life to suit our own character; of doing as we like, subject to such consequences as may follow: without impediment from our fellow-creatures, so long as what we do does not harm them, even though they should think our conduct foolish, perverse, or wrong. Thirdly, from this liberty of each individual, follows the liberty, within the same limits, of combination among individuals; freedom to unite, for any purpose not involving harm to others: the persons combining being supposed to be of full age, and not forced or deceived.
D: Elegant: Where conduct affects only the individual, or others only with their free consent, liberty is absolute. It has three dimensions: freedom of thought and expression, which are inseparable; freedom to live according to one's own character without interference; and freedom to associate with others for any harmless purpose. Together, these define what it means for a society to be free.
D: Summary: Individual liberty covers three domains: freedom of thought and expression, freedom to shape one's own life, and freedom of voluntary association. These apply to all conduct that affects only the individual or others only with their free consent.
D: Distilled: Liberty means freedom of thought, freedom to live as you choose, and freedom to associate -- in everything that harms no one else.
Notes:
Mill's three-part taxonomy of liberty -- thought/expression, lifestyle/pursuits, and association -- has become foundational to liberal political theory and constitutional law.

The qualification 'free, voluntary, and undeceived consent' is significant. Mill does not simply say 'consent' but specifies that it must be informed and uncoerced, anticipating modern concerns about manipulation, fraud, and power imbalances in consensual relationships.

Mill's acknowledgment that 'whatever affects himself, may affect others through himself' signals his awareness of the most common objection to his principle. The question of whether truly self-regarding conduct exists has generated centuries of debate. Mill promises to address this 'in the sequel' -- primarily in Chapter IV of On Liberty.

Freedom of expression 'may seem to fall under a different principle' because speech has effects on others. Mill's argument for treating it as inseparable from freedom of thought anticipates the modern legal doctrine that expression is protected not primarily for the speaker's sake but because the free exchange of ideas serves the public interest (a rationale later developed by Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes in his 'marketplace of ideas' metaphor, Abrams v. United States, 1919).

D: Refashioned:
No society that fails to respect these liberties deserves to be called free, regardless of its form of government. And no society is fully free unless these liberties are absolute and unqualified.

The only freedom worthy of the name is the freedom to pursue one's own good in one's own way, so long as one does not deprive others of theirs or obstruct their efforts to obtain it. Each person is the proper guardian of their own well-being -- physical, mental, and spiritual. Humanity gains far more by allowing individuals to live as they judge best than by compelling everyone to conform to the judgments of others.
D: Original: No society in which these liberties are not, on the whole, respected, is free, whatever may be its form of government; and none is completely free in which they do not exist absolute and unqualified. The only freedom which deserves the name, is that of pursuing our own good in our own way, so long as we do not attempt to deprive others of theirs, or impede their efforts to obtain it. Each is the proper guardian of his own health, whether bodily, or mental and spiritual. Mankind are greater gainers by suffering each other to live as seems good to themselves, than by compelling each to live as seems good to the rest.
D: Elegant: No society is free that does not respect these liberties, whatever its form of government. The only freedom worthy of the name is the freedom to pursue your own good in your own way, without depriving others of theirs. Each person is the rightful guardian of their own well-being. Humanity gains more from tolerating individual difference than from enforcing collective conformity.
D: Summary: A society is free only if it respects liberty of thought, lifestyle, and association without qualification. True freedom means pursuing one's own good in one's own way. Society benefits more from individual self-determination than from enforced conformity.
D: Distilled: The only freedom worthy of the name is pursuing your own good in your own way, without depriving others of theirs.
Notes:
Mill's claim that liberty must be 'absolute and unqualified' is his strongest formulation. In practice, later chapters introduce nuances and exceptions, but the rhetorical force here is deliberate: Mill wants to establish the presumption in favor of liberty as the default, with any restriction requiring justification.

'Each is the proper guardian of his own health, whether bodily, or mental and spiritual' -- This assertion of individual sovereignty over one's own welfare is the philosophical foundation for opposing paternalistic legislation. It has been invoked in debates over drug policy, seatbelt laws, assisted suicide, and personal health choices.

The argument that 'mankind are greater gainers by suffering each other to live as seems good to themselves' is both a moral claim and an empirical one. Mill elaborates the empirical case in Chapter III (On Individuality), arguing that diversity of character and lifestyle drives social progress through experimentation and innovation.

D: Refashioned:
