This principle, though it may sound like a truism, directly opposes the dominant tendency of every era. Societies have always devoted enormous effort to enforcing conformity with prevailing standards of personal conduct -- often more effort than they devote to genuinely social obligations.

In the ancient world, both governments and philosophers considered the state entitled to regulate nearly every aspect of private life, on the grounds that it had a deep interest in the physical and mental discipline of every citizen. In small republics surrounded by powerful enemies and constantly threatened by invasion or civil unrest, this was understandable. Survival seemed to require constant vigilance, and they felt unable to wait for the slower benefits of individual freedom.

In the modern world, larger political communities and the separation of church and state prevented governments from exercising the same legal control over private conduct. But social pressure filled the gap. Moral repression has often been directed more fiercely against personal nonconformity than against genuinely antisocial behavior. Religion, one of the most powerful forces shaping moral sentiment, has been driven either by institutional ambition to govern every aspect of life or by a puritanical impulse toward rigid discipline.

Nor have secular reformers always been more tolerant. Auguste Comte's System of Positive Polity envisioned a moral despotism of society over the individual more extensive than anything imagined by the strictest ancient philosophers -- achieved through social pressure rather than law, but no less totalizing in its ambitions.
D: Original:
Though this doctrine is anything but new, and, to some persons, may have the air of a truism, there is no doctrine which stands more directly opposed to the general tendency of existing opinion and practice. Society has expended fully as much effort in the attempt (according to its lights) to compel people to conform to its notions of personal, as of social excellence. The ancient commonwealths thought themselves entitled to practise, and the ancient philosophers countenanced, the regulation of every part of private conduct by public authority, on the ground that the State had a deep interest in the whole bodily and mental discipline of every one of its citizens; a mode of thinking which may have been admissible in small republics surrounded by powerful enemies, in constant peril of being subverted by foreign attack or internal commotion, and to which even a short interval of relaxed energy and self-command might so easily be fatal, that they could not afford to wait for the salutary permanent effects of freedom. In the modern world, the greater size of political communities, and above all, the separation between spiritual and temporal authority (which placed the direction of men’s consciences in other hands than those which controlled their worldly affairs), prevented so great an interference by law in the details of private life; but the engines of moral repression have been wielded more strenuously against divergence from the reigning opinion in self-regarding, than even in social matters; religion, the most powerful of the elements which have entered into the formation of moral feeling, having almost always been governed either by the ambition of a hierarchy, seeking control over every department of human conduct, or by the spirit of Puritanism. And some of those modern reformers who have placed themselves in strongest opposition to the religions of the past, have been noway behind either churches or sects in their assertion of the right of spiritual domination: M. Comte, in particular, whose social system, as unfolded in his
Système de Politique Positive, aims at establishing (though by moral more than by legal appliances) a despotism of society over the individual, surpassing anything contemplated in the political ideal of the most rigid disciplinarian among the ancient philosophers.
D: Elegant: This principle sounds obvious. It is anything but. Every society has devoted enormous energy to enforcing conformity in personal conduct. Ancient states regulated private life openly; modern states rely on social pressure instead of law, but the impulse is the same. Religion enforces it through doctrine, puritanism through shame, and even secular reformers like Comte have proposed systems of social control more comprehensive than any ancient philosopher imagined.
D: Summary: Despite sounding obvious, the principle of individual liberty directly opposes the persistent tendency of societies to enforce personal conformity. This tendency has manifested through state regulation in ancient republics, religious moral authority, and even secular reform movements like Comte's positivism.
D: Distilled: Every society claims to value individual freedom; every society devotes enormous energy to suppressing it.
Notes:
Ancient commonwealths -- Mill refers primarily to Sparta and to Plato's Republic, which prescribed detailed regulation of citizens' lives including diet, exercise, education, sexual conduct, and artistic expression.

The separation between spiritual and temporal authority -- The investiture controversy (11th-12th centuries) and the gradual separation of church and state that followed the Reformation. This separation, Mill argues, paradoxically reduced legal control over private life while increasing informal social control.

Puritanism -- Both the historical Puritan movement (16th-17th centuries) and the broader cultural tendency toward moral rigorism. Mill saw Puritan influence as particularly strong in Victorian England and in New England.

Auguste Comte (1798-1857) -- French philosopher, founder of positivism and sociology. His Systeme de Politique Positive (1851-1854) proposed a 'Religion of Humanity' with detailed prescriptions for personal conduct enforced through social opinion. Mill initially admired Comte but became increasingly critical, publishing Auguste Comte and Positivism (1865) partly to distance himself.

Mill's comparison of Comte to 'the most rigid disciplinarian among the ancient philosophers' likely refers to Plato and to the Stoics, whose philosophy prescribed detailed regulation of personal life in pursuit of virtue.

D: Refashioned:
Beyond the theories of individual thinkers, there is a broad and growing tendency worldwide to expand society's power over the individual, through both public opinion and law. Every major development in the modern world strengthens collective institutions while weakening individual resistance. This encroachment will not reverse itself; it is likely to intensify.

The impulse to impose one's own opinions and preferences on others is one of the deepest features of human nature, fueled equally by compassion and by contempt, by moral conviction and by tribal instinct. It is restrained only when people lack the power to act on it. As society's collective power grows, only a strong moral conviction in favor of individual liberty can check its expansion. Without that conviction, the pressure toward conformity will continue to increase.
D: Original: Apart from the peculiar tenets of individual thinkers, there is also in the world at large an increasing inclination to stretch unduly the powers of society over the individual, both by the force of opinion and even by that of legislation: and as the tendency of all the changes taking place in the world is to strengthen society, and diminish the power of the individual, this encroachment is not one of the evils which tend spontaneously to disappear, but, on the contrary, to grow more and more formidable. The disposition of mankind, whether as rulers or as fellow-citizens, to impose their own opinions and inclinations as a rule of conduct on others, is so energetically supported by some of the best and by some of the worst feelings incident to human nature, that it is hardly ever kept under restraint by anything but want of power; and as the power is not declining, but growing, unless a strong barrier of moral conviction can be raised against the mischief, we must expect, in the present circumstances of the world, to see it increase.
D: Elegant: The tendency to extend society's power over individuals is growing, not shrinking. Every modern development strengthens collective institutions and weakens individual resistance. The impulse to impose one's views on others is restrained only by lack of power -- and power is not declining. Without a strong moral conviction in favor of liberty, conformity will tighten its grip.
D: Summary: Society's power over individuals is growing through both opinion and law, and modern developments reinforce this trend. The human impulse to impose conformity is checked only by lack of power, and that power is increasing. Only a firm moral commitment to individual liberty can resist this trajectory.
D: Distilled: The impulse to impose conformity is checked only by lack of power -- and society's power is growing, not shrinking.
Notes:
Mill's warning about the growing power of society over individuals anticipates several major developments: the expansion of the administrative state in the late 19th and 20th centuries, the rise of mass media and its capacity to enforce cultural conformity, and the emergence of totalitarian regimes that claimed to express the people's will.

'Supported by some of the best and by some of the worst feelings incident to human nature' -- Mill recognizes that the impulse to control others is not simply malicious. It is often motivated by genuine concern for others' welfare (paternalism) or by sincere moral conviction, which makes it harder to resist than purely self-interested tyranny.

Mill's prediction that encroachment on liberty would grow 'more and more formidable' has been validated by developments he could not have foreseen: digital surveillance, algorithmic content moderation, social media mob dynamics, and the capacity of modern states and corporations to monitor and influence individual behavior at unprecedented scale.

The call for 'a strong barrier of moral conviction' reflects Mill's belief that institutional safeguards alone are insufficient. Liberty requires a culture that values it -- a point he develops throughout the remainder of On Liberty.

D: Refashioned:
Rather than addressing the full scope of this argument at once, I will begin with one branch where the underlying principle is already partly recognized: the liberty of thought, and with it the inseparable liberty of speaking and writing. These freedoms are acknowledged, to some degree, in every society that claims to support free institutions and religious tolerance. Yet the philosophical and practical reasons that justify them are less widely understood than one might expect, even among prominent public voices.

Once properly grasped, these reasons extend far beyond questions of thought and expression alone. A careful examination of this single branch of liberty will provide the strongest foundation for understanding the rest. The topic has been debated for centuries, but I ask the reader's patience as I take it up once more.
D: Original: It will be convenient for the argument, if, instead of at once entering upon the general thesis, we confine ourselves in the first instance to a single branch of it, on which the principle here stated is, if not fully, yet to a certain point, recognised by the current opinions. This one branch is the Liberty of Thought: from which it is impossible to separate the cognate liberty of speaking and of writing. Although these liberties, to some considerable amount, form part of the political morality of all countries which profess religious toleration and free institutions, the grounds, both philosophical and practical, on which they rest, are perhaps not so familiar to the general mind, nor so thoroughly appreciated by many even of the leaders of opinion, as might have been expected. Those grounds, when rightly understood, are of much wider application than to only one division of the subject, and a thorough consideration of this part of the question will be found the best introduction to the remainder. Those to whom nothing which I am about to say will be new, may therefore, I hope, excuse me, if on a subject which for now three centuries has been so often discussed, I venture on one discussion more.
D: Elegant: I begin with the liberty of thought, speech, and writing -- where the principle is already partly accepted. Even so, the reasons that justify these freedoms are poorly understood, even by those who defend them. And those reasons, once grasped, reach far beyond expression itself. They illuminate the entire argument for individual liberty.
D: Summary: The essay will begin with freedom of thought and expression, where the principle of liberty is already partly recognized. The philosophical foundations of these freedoms are less understood than expected, and once grasped, they apply to the broader argument about individual liberty.
D: Distilled: Freedom of thought is where the argument for liberty is strongest and most widely accepted -- and it illuminates all the rest.
Notes:
Mill's decision to begin with freedom of thought and expression is strategic. By starting with the most widely accepted form of liberty, he can establish principles that he will then extend to more controversial domains (individuality, lifestyle choices, limits of social authority) in later chapters.

'For now three centuries' -- Mill dates the debate over freedom of thought and expression to the Reformation era (early 16th century), when the printing press and Protestant challenges to Catholic authority made censorship and free expression central political issues.

Key figures in the three-century tradition Mill references include: John Milton (Areopagitica, 1644), the first major English-language argument against censorship; John Locke (A Letter Concerning Toleration, 1689); Voltaire (Letters on the English, 1733; Treatise on Tolerance, 1763); and Thomas Jefferson and James Madison (the First Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, ratified 1791).

Mill's Chapter II (Of the Liberty of Thought and Discussion) became one of the most influential defenses of free expression ever written, providing arguments still cited in legal decisions and philosophical debates about censorship, hate speech, and the limits of permissible discourse.

D: Refashioned:
The case for press freedom against tyrannical government has been made so thoroughly by earlier writers that it hardly needs restating. Even in England, where press laws technically remain as restrictive as under the Tudors, the real risk of government censorship of political speech is minimal -- except in moments of collective panic, when fear overrides principle. In functioning democracies, government rarely tries to suppress opinion on its own initiative. When it does, it acts as an instrument of something more dangerous: the intolerance of the public itself.

So let us set aside the easy case of a government opposed to its people. Suppose instead a government perfectly aligned with popular will, suppressing only what the majority wants suppressed. I deny its right to do so. That power is illegitimate no matter who wields it. The best government has no more title to silence dissent than the worst. Coercion of opinion is most dangerous precisely when it reflects popular sentiment -- because then it faces the least resistance.
D: Original:
THE TIME, it is to be hoped, is gone by, when any defence would be necessary of the “liberty of the press” as one of the securities against corrupt or tyrannical government. No argument, we may suppose, can now be needed, against permitting a legislature or an executive, not identified in interest with the people, to prescribe opinions to them, and determine what doctrines or what arguments they shall be allowed to hear. This aspect of the question, besides, has been so often and so triumphantly enforced by preceding writers, that it needs not be specially insisted on in this place. Though the law of England, on the subject of the press, is as servile to this day as it was in the time of the Tudors, there is little danger of its being actually put in force against political discussion, except during some temporary panic, when fear of insurrection drives ministers and judges from their propriety;
*1 and, speaking generally, it is not, in constitutional countries, to be apprehended, that the government, whether completely responsible to the people or not, will often attempt to control the expression of opinion, except when in doing so it makes itself the organ of the general intolerance of the public. Let us suppose, therefore, that the government is entirely at one with the people, and never thinks of exerting any power of coercion unless in agreement with what it conceives to be their voice. But I deny the right of the people to exercise such coercion, either by themselves or by their government. The power itself is illegitimate. The best government has no more title to it than the worst. It is as noxious, or more noxious, when exerted in accordance with public opinion, than when in opposition to it.
D: Elegant: The old battle was against governments that silenced dissent. The new battle is harder: against a public that demands the silencing, and a government happy to oblige. Censorship backed by popular will is not more legitimate than censorship imposed against it. It is more dangerous -- because it meets less resistance.
D: Summary: Government censorship of political opinion is largely a settled issue in democracies. The greater threat is the coercion of opinion by the public itself, which is illegitimate regardless of majority support.
D: Distilled: Censorship is most dangerous not when imposed by tyrants against the people, but when demanded by the people themselves.
Notes:
[Tudor-era press censorship] (1485-1603) -- England's historically restrictive press laws dating to the Star Chamber and licensing acts.
[Constitutional press freedom arguments] -- Mill references the tradition from Milton's Areopagitica (1644) through Locke, acknowledging this ground is well-covered.
[Government Press Prosecutions of 1858] -- Referenced via the footnote marker *1; Mill was writing as these occurred.
[Tyranny of the majority] -- A concept Mill inherits from Tocqueville's Democracy in America (1835/1840), which warned that democratic societies could produce conformity more oppressive than monarchical rule.

D: Refashioned:
If every person on earth but one shared the same opinion, the majority would be no more justified in silencing that lone dissenter than he, if he had the power, would be justified in silencing them all.

This is not about protecting individual feelings. If an opinion were merely a personal possession -- like a taste in music or food -- then suppressing it would be a private injury, and scale would matter. But silencing an opinion is something far worse: it robs the entire human race, present and future. If the suppressed opinion is right, everyone loses the chance to replace error with truth. If it is wrong, everyone loses something nearly as valuable -- the sharper, more vital understanding of truth that comes only from its collision with error.
D: Original: If all mankind minus one, were of one opinion, and only one person were of the contrary opinion, mankind would be no more justified in silencing that one person, than he, if he had the power, would be justified in silencing mankind. Were an opinion a personal possession of no value except to the owner; if to be obstructed in the enjoyment of it were simply a private injury, it would make some difference whether the injury was inflicted only on a few persons or on many. But the peculiar evil of silencing the expression of an opinion is, that it is robbing the human race; posterity as well as the existing generation; those who dissent from the opinion, still more than those who hold it. If the opinion is right, they are deprived of the opportunity of exchanging error for truth: if wrong, they lose, what is almost as great a benefit, the clearer perception and livelier impression of truth, produced by its collision with error.
D: Elegant: Silence one dissenter and you rob not just that person but every person, born and unborn. If the suppressed view is right, the world loses truth. If wrong, it loses the only process by which truth stays alive: confrontation with its opposite.
D: Summary: Silencing even one opinion harms all of humanity. A correct opinion lost means truth denied; an incorrect opinion lost means truth weakened by never being tested.
D: Distilled: Suppressing an opinion robs the human race -- of truth if the opinion is right, and of clarity if it is wrong.
Notes:
[The epistemic argument for free speech] -- Mill's foundational claim: free expression benefits not primarily the speaker but society at large.
[Error-correction as social good] -- This anticipates Karl Popper's later philosophy of science, where knowledge advances through falsification.
[Posterity argument] -- Mill extends the harm of censorship across time, arguing future generations are also victims of present suppression.

D: Refashioned: Shortly after writing this chapter, the Government Press Prosecutions of 1858 seemed to contradict my claim that political censorship was fading. But the cases were quickly abandoned and were never truly political -- the charge was promoting the doctrine that tyrannicide is lawful, not criticizing government. Their collapse actually confirmed the argument: attempts at suppression in a society accustomed to open discussion tend to fail.
D: Original: These words had scarcely been written, when, as if to give them an emphatic contradiction, occurred the Government Press Prosecutions of 1858. That ill-judged interference with the liberty of public discussion has not, however, induced me to alter a single word in the text, nor has it at all weakened my conviction that, moments of panic excepted, the era of pains and penalties for political discussion has, in our own country, passed away. For, in the first place, the prosecutions were not persisted in; and, in the second, they were never, properly speaking, political prosecutions. The offence charged was not that of criticising institutions, or the acts or persons of rulers, but of circulating what was deemed an immoral doctrine, the lawfulness of Tyrannicide.
D: Elegant: The 1858 prosecutions seemed a rebuttal -- until they collapsed, proving the point. In a culture of open discussion, censorship cannot sustain itself.
D: Summary: The 1858 Government Press Prosecutions targeted the doctrine of tyrannicide, not political criticism. Their swift abandonment confirmed that political censorship was unsustainable in Britain.
D: Distilled: The failure of the 1858 press prosecutions proved that a culture of open discussion naturally resists censorship.
Notes:
[Government Press Prosecutions of 1858] -- Prosecutions brought against publishers who circulated arguments defending tyrannicide (the killing of tyrants), prompted partly by Felice Orsini's assassination attempt on Napoleon III (January 14, 1858).
[Doctrine of tyrannicide] -- The philosophical position, with roots in classical antiquity (Cicero, Brutus), that killing a tyrant is morally justified.
[Felice Orsini] (1819-1858) -- Italian revolutionary whose bomb attack on Napoleon III in Paris triggered diplomatic pressure on Britain to prosecute those who had published pro-tyrannicide arguments from London.

D: Refashioned: The argument against censorship has two branches, and both must be considered. First, we can never be certain the opinion we suppress is actually false. But second -- and this is the stronger claim -- even if we could be certain it was false, suppressing it would still be harmful.
D: Original: It is necessary to consider separately these two hypotheses, each of which has a distinct branch of the argument corresponding to it. We can never be sure that the opinion we are endeavouring to stifle is a false opinion; and if we were sure, stifling it would be an evil still.
D: Elegant: Two reasons never to silence a belief: you might be wrong about it, and even if you are right, silencing it still does damage.
D: Summary: Censorship fails on two grounds: the suppressed opinion might be true, and even certain falsehood is better challenged than silenced.
D: Distilled: Suppression is wrong whether the silenced opinion is true or false -- the case against censorship holds in both directions.
Notes: [Structure of the chapter] -- Mill here lays out the architecture of Chapter 2: he will argue first that the suppressed opinion may be true (2.4-2.23), then that even true received opinions need challenge (2.24-2.36), then that truth is typically divided between opposing views (2.37-2.42).

D: Refashioned:
Start with the first possibility: the opinion being suppressed might actually be true. Its suppressors naturally deny this -- but they are not infallible. No one has the authority to decide a question for all of humanity and deny everyone else the means of judging. To silence an opinion because you are sure it is false is to treat your certainty as absolute certainty. All censorship rests on an assumption of infallibility.

Everyone acknowledges their own fallibility in theory. Almost no one acts on it. People rarely consider that the beliefs they hold most confidently might be among the errors they admit they are prone to. Those accustomed to power and deference -- rulers, executives, public figures -- feel this unwarranted confidence most acutely. But even ordinary people display a version of it: they simply outsource their certainty to their social circle. "The world" to most people means their party, their demographic, their media ecosystem, their nation at most. And this confidence is rarely shaken by the obvious fact that people in other circles, other countries, other centuries hold or held the exact opposite views with equal conviction.

The same accident of birth that makes someone a political conservative in Texas would have made them a communist in Soviet Moscow or a Buddhist in Lhasa. Yet people treat the worldview they inherited as if it were arrived at by rigorous reasoning. Entire eras are no more infallible than individuals. Every age has held beliefs that later generations found not merely false but absurd. It is certain that some of our own confident beliefs will meet the same fate.
D: Original:
First: the opinion which it is attempted to suppress by authority may possibly be true. Those who desire to suppress it, of course deny its truth; but they are not infallible. They have no authority to decide the question for all mankind, and exclude every other person from the means of judging. To refuse a hearing to an opinion, because they are sure that it is false, is to assume that
their certainty is the same thing as absolute certainty. All silencing of discussion is an assumption of infallibility. Its condemnation may be allowed to rest on this common argument, not the worse for being common.

Unfortunately for the good sense of mankind, the fact of their fallibility is far from carrying the weight in their practical judgment, which is always allowed to it in theory; for while every one well knows himself to be fallible, few think it necessary to take any precautions against their own fallibility, or admit the supposition that any opinion, of which they feel very certain, may be one of the examples of the error to which they acknowledge themselves to be liable. Absolute princes, or others who are accustomed to unlimited deference, usually feel this complete confidence in their own opinions on nearly all subjects. People more happily situated, who sometimes hear their opinions disputed, and are not wholly unused to be set right when they are wrong, place the same unbounded reliance only on such of their opinions as are shared by all who surround them, or to whom they habitually defer: for in proportion to a man’s want of confidence in his own solitary judgment, does he usually repose, with implicit trust, on the infallibility of “the world” in general. And the world, to each individual, means the part of it with which he comes in contact; his party, his sect, his church, his class of society: the man may be called, by comparison, almost liberal and large-minded to whom it means anything so comprehensive as his own country or his own age. Nor is his faith in this collective authority at all shaken by his being aware that other ages, countries, sects, churches, classes, and parties have thought, and even now think, the exact reverse. He devolves upon his own world the responsibility of being in the right against the dissentient worlds of other people; and it never troubles him that mere accident has decided which of these numerous worlds is the object of his reliance, and that the same causes which make him a Churchman in London, would have made him a Buddhist or a Confucian in Pekin. Yet it is as evident in itself, as any amount of argument can make it, that ages are no more infallible than individuals; every age having held many opinions which subsequent ages have deemed not only false but absurd; and it is as certain that many opinions, now general, will be rejected by future ages, as it is that many, once general, are rejected by the present.
D: Elegant: To silence a view because you are certain it is false is to equate your certainty with infallibility. Everyone admits they are fallible in theory; almost no one behaves accordingly. "The world" whose authority people invoke is usually just their own social circle projected outward. And the same accident that made you who you are would, in another time and place, have made you your own opponent.
D: Summary: Censorship assumes infallibility. People acknowledge fallibility in theory but not in practice, outsourcing their confidence to whatever social group surrounds them. Every era has held beliefs later judged absurd; ours is no exception.
D: Distilled: All censorship is an assumption of infallibility -- and the world whose judgment you trust is usually just your own circle, projected outward.
Notes:
[Assumption of infallibility] -- Mill's central epistemological argument: the act of silencing presupposes certainty no human can possess.
[Social determination of belief] -- Mill anticipates sociology of knowledge (Karl Mannheim, Peter Berger) in observing that beliefs are largely products of social environment.
[Churchman in London... Buddhist in Pekin] -- Mill's original examples of how geography determines belief, illustrating that conviction tracks birthplace more than evidence.
[Historical fallibility of ages] -- Mill draws on the history of science and philosophy: geocentrism, humoralism, divine right of kings, and other once-universal beliefs now rejected.

D: Refashioned:
The obvious rebuttal goes like this: Governments and institutions must act on their best judgment every day. They set policy, allocate resources, make war and peace -- all based on opinions that might be wrong. If the possibility of error paralyzed all action, nothing would ever get done. A government that believes an opinion is dangerous has a duty to act on that belief, just as it has a duty to act on any other policy judgment. The fact that past governments have been wrong about some opinions does not mean present governments should never act against any opinions -- just as the fact that governments have waged unjust wars does not mean they should never wage war at all.

On this view, demanding absolute certainty before acting is not conscience but cowardice. We cannot achieve perfect certainty about anything. But we can reach sufficient confidence for practical decisions. We assume our opinions are true enough to guide our own conduct; why not also true enough to prevent others from spreading what we sincerely believe to be dangerous falsehoods?
D: Original: The objection likely to be made to this argument, would probably take some such form as the following. There is no greater assumption of infallibility in forbidding the propagation of error, than in any other thing which is done by public authority on its own judgment and responsibility. Judgment is given to men that they may use it. Because it may be used erroneously, are men to be told that they ought not to use it at all? To prohibit what they think pernicious, is not claiming exemption from error, but fulfilling the duty incumbent on them, although fallible, of acting on their conscientious conviction. If we were never to act on our opinions, because those opinions may be wrong, we should leave all our interests uncared for, and all our duties unperformed. An objection which applies to all conduct, can be no valid objection to any conduct in particular. It is the duty of governments, and of individuals, to form the truest opinions they can; to form them carefully, and never impose them upon others unless they are quite sure of being right. But when they are sure (such reasoners may say), it is not conscientiousness but cowardice to shrink from acting on their opinions, and allow doctrines which they honestly think dangerous to the welfare of mankind, either in this life or in another, to be scattered abroad without restraint, because other people, in less enlightened times, have persecuted opinions now believed to be true. Let us take care, it may be said, not to make the same mistake: but governments and nations have made mistakes in other things, which are not denied to be fit subjects for the exercise of authority: they have laid on bad taxes, made unjust wars. Ought we therefore to lay on no taxes, and, under whatever provocation, make no wars? Men, and governments, must act to the best of their ability. There is no such thing as absolute certainty, but there is assurance sufficient for the purposes of human life. We may, and must, assume our opinion to be true for the guidance of our own conduct: and it is assuming no more when we forbid bad men to pervert society by the propagation of opinions which we regard as false and pernicious.
D: Elegant: The counterargument sounds practical: governments must act under uncertainty in every domain, so why should opinion be exempt? If we waited for absolute certainty before acting, we would never act at all. Demanding perfect proof before suppressing a dangerous idea is not caution -- it is paralysis.
D: Summary: The strongest objection to Mill's argument: governments routinely act on fallible judgment in all areas. Requiring absolute certainty before suppressing opinion would paralyze all governance, and responsible leaders have a duty to act against what they sincerely believe is dangerous.
D: Distilled: The case for censorship rests on a practical appeal: if fallibility barred all action, nothing would ever get done -- so why should opinion be uniquely exempt?
Notes:
[Steel-manning the opposition] -- Mill's method throughout: he states the strongest version of the opposing argument before dismantling it.
[Analogy to war and taxation] -- The objection draws parallels between suppressing opinion and other government actions taken under uncertainty.
[Duty-based argument for censorship] -- The position that responsible governance requires acting on sincere conviction, even about the danger of ideas.
[Practical certainty vs. absolute certainty] -- A distinction from epistemology: we can have "moral certainty" (sufficient for action) without logical certainty.

D: Refashioned:
This objection collapses on a single distinction. There is a vast difference between treating a belief as true because, after every opportunity to challenge it, no one has managed to refute it -- and treating a belief as true by preventing anyone from trying to refute it. The first earns confidence. The second manufactures it.

The only thing that can justify acting on a belief is that it has survived open, unrestricted challenge. Without that, no human being can claim rational confidence in being right. Governments act on judgment in every domain, true -- but in every other domain, the judgment can be questioned. The moment you declare an opinion too dangerous to challenge, you remove the only process that could make your confidence legitimate.
D: Original: I answer, that it is assuming very much more. There is the greatest difference between presuming an opinion to be true, because, with every opportunity for contesting it, it has not been refuted, and assuming its truth for the purpose of not permitting its refutation. Complete liberty of contradicting and disproving our opinion, is the very condition which justifies us in assuming its truth for purposes of action; and on no other terms can a being with human faculties have any rational assurance of being right.
D: Elegant: There is all the difference in the world between believing something because it has survived every challenge, and believing it because you have forbidden the challenge. One earns confidence. The other counterfeits it.
D: Summary: The right to act on a belief depends on that belief having been open to challenge. Confidence earned through surviving criticism is legitimate; confidence maintained by forbidding criticism is not.
D: Distilled: Confidence in a belief is earned by surviving challenge, not by forbidding it.
Notes:
[Falsificationism avant la lettre] -- Mill's argument here closely anticipates Karl Popper's principle that a theory's strength comes from its surviving attempts at falsification, not from being shielded from them.
[Open society epistemology] -- The idea that legitimate knowledge requires institutional openness to challenge -- foundational to Popper's The Open Society and Its Enemies (1945).
[Distinction between presumption and prohibition] -- Mill's key logical move: acting on a presumption of truth is categorically different from enforcing that presumption by silencing dissent.

D: Refashioned:
Consider why human thought and conduct are not worse than they are. It is not because most people are good at reasoning -- on any non-obvious question, the vast majority cannot reason well, and even the most brilliant minds of past generations held beliefs we now recognize as false. The real reason humanity has progressed is that our errors are correctable. We can fix our mistakes through discussion and experience -- but not through experience alone. Raw experience does not interpret itself. Facts need argument to extract their meaning.

The entire value of human judgment depends on this one property: that it can be corrected when wrong. And it can only be corrected if the means of correction -- open criticism, opposing argument, diverse perspectives -- remain constantly available.

Look at any person whose judgment genuinely deserves trust. How did they earn it? By keeping their mind open to criticism. By making it a practice to hear everything that could be said against their position. By engaging seriously with people who see the world differently. By seeking out objections rather than avoiding them. No one has ever become wise any other way.

Far from making a person hesitant or indecisive, this habit of testing one's views against all comers is the only stable foundation for confidence in those views. Having heard the strongest objections and answered them, having let in every available light on the question, such a person has earned the right to trust their judgment -- more than any person or any crowd that has not done the same work.
D: Original: When we consider either the history of opinion, or the ordinary conduct of human life, to what is it to be ascribed that the one and the other are no worse than they are? Not certainly to the inherent force of the human understanding; for, on any matter not self-evident, there are ninety-nine persons totally incapable of judging of it, for one who is capable; and the capacity of the hundredth person is only comparative; for the majority of the eminent men of every past generation held many opinions now known to be erroneous, and did or approved numerous things which no one will now justify. Why is it, then, that there is on the whole a preponderance among mankind of rational opinions and rational conduct? If there really is this preponderance—which there must be unless human affairs are, and have always been, in an almost desperate state—it is owing to a quality of the human mind, the source of everything respectable in man either as an intellectual or as a moral being, namely, that his errors are corrigible. He is capable of rectifying his mistakes, by discussion and experience. Not by experience alone. There must be discussion, to show how experience is to be interpreted. Wrong opinions and practices gradually yield to fact and argument: but facts and arguments, to produce any effect on the mind, must be brought before it. Very few facts are able to tell their own story, without comments to bring out their meaning. The whole strength and value, then, of human judgment, depending on the one property, that it can be set right when it is wrong, reliance can be placed on it only when the means of setting it right are kept constantly at hand. In the case of any person whose judgment is really deserving of confidence, how has it become so? Because he has kept his mind open to criticism of his opinions and conduct. Because it has been his practice to listen to all that could be said against him; to profit by as much of it as was just, and expound to himself, and upon occasion to others, the fallacy of what was fallacious. Because he has felt, that the only way in which a human being can make some approach to knowing the whole of a subject, is by hearing what can be said about it by persons of every variety of opinion, and studying all modes in which it can be looked at by every character of mind. No wise man ever acquired his wisdom in any mode but this; nor is it in the nature of human intellect to become wise in any other manner. The steady habit of correcting and completing his own opinion by collating it with those of others, so far from causing doubt and hesitation in carrying it into practice, is the only stable foundation for a just reliance on it: for, being cognisant of all that can, at least obviously, be said against him, and having taken up his position against all gainsayers—knowing that he has sought for objections and difficulties, instead of avoiding them, and has shut out no light which can be thrown upon the subject from any quarter—he has a right to think his judgment better than that of any person, or any multitude, who have not gone through a similar process.
D: Elegant: Human judgment has exactly one virtue: it can be corrected. Remove the means of correction -- open challenge, honest criticism, opposing perspectives -- and that virtue dies. The wisest people are not those born with superior insight but those who have made a discipline of hearing every argument against them. Certainty earned through confrontation is the only certainty worth having.
D: Summary: Human progress depends not on innate reasoning ability but on the capacity to correct errors through discussion. Trustworthy judgment is built by systematically exposing one's beliefs to criticism, not by shielding them from it.
D: Distilled: Wisdom is not native intelligence but the disciplined habit of exposing your beliefs to the strongest possible objections.
Notes:
[Corrigibility as the source of progress] -- Mill's epistemology: human advancement rests not on getting things right initially but on the capacity to revise.
[Discussion vs. experience alone] -- Mill argues that experience without interpretive discussion is insufficient -- facts do not speak for themselves.
[The hundredth person] -- Mill's observation that even the most capable thinkers of past generations held many beliefs now known to be false.
[Epistemic humility through practice] -- Mill describes what modern epistemologists call "active open-mindedness" -- the deliberate seeking of disconfirming evidence.

D: Refashioned:
If the wisest individuals require open challenge to trust their own judgment, why should the general public -- that collection of a few thoughtful people and many unreflective ones -- demand a lower standard?

Even the Catholic Church, hardly known for intellectual openness, requires a devil's advocate before canonizing a saint. The holiest candidate cannot receive posthumous honors until every possible objection has been heard and weighed. If even Newtonian physics had been shielded from questioning, our confidence in it would be less secure, not more.

The beliefs we are most justified in holding rest on nothing but a standing invitation for the entire world to prove them wrong. If no one takes up the challenge, or all who try fail, we still lack absolute certainty -- but we have done the best that human reason allows. We have neglected nothing that could give truth a chance of reaching us. And if a better understanding exists, keeping the arena open ensures it will eventually be found -- when the human mind is ready to receive it.
D: Original: It is not too much to require that what the wisest of mankind, those who are best entitled to trust their own judgment, find necessary to warrant their relying on it, should be submitted to by that miscellaneous collection of a few wise and many foolish individuals, called the public. The most intolerant of churches, the Roman Catholic Church, even at the canonization of a saint, admits, and listens patiently to, a “devil’s advocate.” The holiest of men, it appears, cannot be admitted to posthumous honours, until all that the devil could say against him is known and weighed. If even the Newtonian philosophy were not permitted to be questioned, mankind could not feel as complete assurance of its truth as they now do. The beliefs which we have most warrant for, have no safeguard to rest on, but a standing invitation to the whole world to prove them unfounded. If the challenge is not accepted, or is accepted and the attempt fails, we are far enough from certainty still; but we have done the best that the existing state of human reason admits of; we have neglected nothing that could give the truth a chance of reaching us: if the lists are kept open, we may hope that if there be a better truth, it will be found when the human mind is capable of receiving it; and in the meantime we may rely on having attained such approach to truth, as is possible in our own day. This is the amount of certainty attainable by a fallible being, and this the sole way of attaining it.
D: Elegant: Even the Catholic Church appoints a devil's advocate before declaring someone a saint. If the holiest candidate must survive every objection, why should any idea be exempt? The beliefs most worthy of confidence are those that rest on a permanent, open invitation to be proven wrong.
D: Summary: Even the most authoritative institutions recognize the need for adversarial testing. Our most justified beliefs rest on a standing invitation for anyone to disprove them, not on protection from challenge.
D: Distilled: A belief worth holding rests not on protection from doubt but on a standing invitation for the world to prove it wrong.
Notes:
[Devil's advocate (Advocatus Diaboli)] -- Formal role in Catholic canonization proceedings, established by Pope Sixtus V in 1587, tasked with arguing against the candidate's sainthood. Abolished by Pope John Paul II in 1983.
[Newtonian philosophy] -- Mill uses Newton's physics as his example of a supremely well-established scientific framework that nonetheless benefits from remaining open to question. By Mill's time, some limitations of Newtonian mechanics were already being explored.
[Fallibilism] -- The philosophical position that no belief can be held with absolute certainty -- associated with Charles Sanders Peirce (who developed it formally after Mill) and later with Popper.

D: Refashioned:
It is strange that people who accept the argument for free discussion in general will object to pushing it to extremes. If the principle does not hold in extreme cases, it does not hold at all. People who insist on free discussion for everything debatable but carve out exceptions for principles they consider absolutely certain are making the very assumption of infallibility they claim to reject. They are simply drawing the line at their own convictions and declaring those beyond question.

To call any proposition certain while there exists someone who would deny it -- but is not permitted to -- is to make yourself the judge of certainty without hearing the other side. That is not confidence. It is presumption.
D: Original:
Strange it is, that men should admit the validity of the arguments for free discussion, but object to their being “pushed to an extreme;” not seeing that unless the reasons are good for an extreme case, they are not good for any case. Strange that they should imagine that they are not assuming infallibility, when they acknowledge that there should be free discussion on all subjects which can possibly be
doubtful, but think that some particular principle or doctrine should be forbidden to be questioned because it is so
certain, that is, because
they are certain that it is certain. To call any proposition certain, while there is any one who would deny its certainty if permitted, but who is not permitted, is to assume that we ourselves, and those who agree with us, are the judges of certainty, and judges without hearing the other side.
D: Elegant: Principles that fail in extreme cases are not principles at all. Carving out exceptions for beliefs you consider absolutely certain is just infallibility wearing a more modest disguise.
D: Summary: Accepting free discussion in general but exempting certain "certain" beliefs is a disguised assumption of infallibility. If the principle does not apply to extreme cases, it applies to none.
D: Distilled: A principle of free discussion that carves out exceptions for beliefs you consider unquestionable is no principle at all.
Notes:
[Extreme case reasoning] -- Mill applies a standard logical test: a principle that fails at its limits is not a genuine principle.
[Self-referential infallibility] -- The circularity Mill identifies: declaring something too certain to question presupposes the very certainty that questioning would test.
[No-exception principle] -- Mill insists that free speech protections must be absolute in scope to be meaningful -- a position that remains contested in contemporary free speech debates.

D: Refashioned:
In our era -- anxious rather than faithful, clinging to beliefs not because they are true but because people would not know how to function without them -- the case for protecting opinions from attack shifts from truth to utility. The argument becomes: some beliefs are so essential to social stability that governments have a duty to uphold them, just as they protect any other vital public interest. You do not need to be infallible to recognize a load-bearing wall.

This looks like a clever escape from the infallibility problem, but it is not. Shifting from "this belief is true" to "this belief is useful" merely relocates the assumption. Whether an opinion is useful is itself an opinion -- just as debatable, just as requiring of open discussion, as the original claim. You still need an infallible judge to declare a belief harmful unless the belief has full opportunity to defend itself.

And the truth-utility distinction collapses under scrutiny. You cannot fairly assess whether a belief is useful without asking whether it is true. Truth is part of utility. The best minds in every era have held that no false belief can ultimately serve society well. You cannot forbid people from defending the truth of their opinions while allowing them to argue only about usefulness -- the two are inseparable. In practice, when a society prohibits questioning a belief's truth, it equally refuses to tolerate questioning its usefulness. The most it permits is quibbling about how strictly the belief must be enforced.
D: Original:
In the present age—which has been described as “destitute of faith, but terrified at scepticism”—in which people feel sure, not so much that their opinions are true, as that they should not know what to do without them—the claims of an opinion to be protected from public attack are rested not so much on its truth, as on its importance to society. There are, it is alleged, certain beliefs, so useful, not to say indispensable to well-being, that it is as much the duty of governments to uphold those beliefs, as to protect any other of the interests of society. In a case of such necessity, and so directly in the line of their duty, something less than infallibility may, it is maintained, warrant, and even bind, governments, to act on their own opinion, confirmed by the general opinion of mankind. It is also often argued, and still oftener thought, that none but bad men would desire to weaken these salutary beliefs; and there can be nothing wrong, it is thought, in restraining bad men, and prohibiting what only such men would wish to practise. This mode of thinking makes the justification of restraints on discussion not a question of the truth of doctrines, but of their usefulness; and flatters itself by that means to escape the responsibility of claiming to be an infallible judge of opinions. But those who thus satisfy themselves, do not perceive that the assumption of infallibility is merely shifted from one point to another. The usefulness of an opinion is itself matter of opinion: as disputable, as open to discussion, and requiring discussion as much, as the opinion itself. There is the same need of an infallible judge of opinions to decide an opinion to be noxious, as to decide it to be false, unless the opinion condemned has full opportunity of defending itself. And it will not do to say that the heretic may be allowed to maintain the utility or harmlessness of his opinion, though forbidden to maintain its truth. The truth of an opinion is part of its utility. If we would know whether or not it is desirable that a proposition should be believed, is it possible to exclude the consideration of whether or not it is true? In the opinion, not of bad men, but of the best men, no belief which is contrary to truth can be really useful: and can you prevent such men from urging that plea, when they are charged with culpability for denying some doctrine which they are told is useful, but which they believe to be false? Those who are on the side of received opinions, never fail to take all possible advantage of this plea; you do not find
them handling the question of utility as if it could be completely abstracted from that of truth: on the contrary, it is, above all, because their doctrine is the “truth,” that the knowledge or the belief of it is held to be so indispensable. There can be no fair discussion of the question of usefulness, when an argument so vital may be employed on one side, but not on the other. And in point of fact, when law or public feeling do not permit the truth of an opinion to be disputed, they are just as little tolerant of a denial of its usefulness. The utmost they allow is an extenuation of its absolute necessity, or of the positive guilt of rejecting it.
D: Elegant: Defending censorship on grounds of utility instead of truth merely relocates the problem. Whether a belief is useful is itself a matter of opinion -- just as disputable, just as needing discussion. And utility cannot be assessed without asking whether the belief is true. The escape route leads right back to the starting point.
D: Summary: Shifting the justification for censorship from truth to social utility does not escape the infallibility problem. Usefulness is itself debatable and cannot be separated from truth. The same open discussion is required to judge both.
D: Distilled: Defending censorship by claiming a belief is too useful to question merely shifts the assumption of infallibility from truth to utility -- and the two cannot be separated.
Notes:
[Destitute of faith, but terrified at scepticism] -- Mill quotes Thomas Carlyle (likely from "Characteristics," 1831), describing the Victorian crisis of belief.
[Utility as a substitute for truth] -- Mill addresses the pragmatic defense of orthodoxy: beliefs valued not for correctness but for social cohesion.
[Social stability argument for religion] -- The position, common from antiquity through the Enlightenment, that religious belief is necessary for public order regardless of its truth. Associated with thinkers from Plato (Noble Lie in the Republic) through Voltaire.
[Inseparability of truth and utility] -- Mill's key logical move: a utilitarian himself, he argues that even on utilitarian grounds, truth-assessment cannot be excluded from utility-assessment.

D: Refashioned:
To make this argument concrete, take the hardest possible case -- the one most unfavorable to my position. Let the belief in question be the existence of God, the afterlife, or fundamental moral principles. If any beliefs deserve legal protection from challenge, surely these do.

But I must clarify what I mean. Feeling certain about a belief -- however certain -- is not what I call an assumption of infallibility. The assumption of infallibility is deciding the question for others: preventing them from hearing the opposing case and judging for themselves. I condemn this equally when it is done in defense of beliefs I hold most deeply.

And far from being less dangerous when applied to beliefs labeled sacred or immoral to question, this is precisely where the assumption of infallibility does the most damage. These are the cases where one generation commits errors that fill later generations with horror. These are the occasions when legal authority has been used to destroy the best people and the most vital ideas -- sometimes successfully destroying the people while the ideas survive, only to be invoked, with bitter irony, to justify the same treatment of the next generation of dissenters.
D: Original:
In order more fully to illustrate the mischief of denying a hearing to opinions because we, in our own judgment, have condemned them, it will be desirable to fix down the discussion to a concrete case; and I choose, by preference, the cases which are least favourable to me—in which the argument against freedom of opinion, both on the score of truth and on that of utility, is considered the strongest. Let the opinions impugned be the belief in a God and in a future state, or any of the commonly received doctrines of morality. To fight the battle on such ground, gives a great advantage to an unfair antagonist; since he will be sure to say (and many who have no desire to be unfair will say it internally), Are these the doctrines which you do not deem sufficiently certain to be taken under the protection of law? Is the belief in a God one of the opinions, to feel sure of which, you hold to be assuming infallibility? But I must be permitted to observe, that it is not the feeling sure of a doctrine (be it what it may) which I call an assumption of infallibility. It is the undertaking to decide that question
for others, without allowing them to hear what can be said on the contrary side. And I denounce and reprobate this pretension not the less, if put forth on the side of my most solemn convictions. However positive any one’s persuasion may be, not only of the falsity but of the pernicious consequences—not only of the pernicious consequences, but (to adopt expressions which I altogether condemn) the immorality and impiety of an opinion; yet if, in pursuance of that private judgment, though backed by the public judgment of his country or his cotemporaries, he prevents the opinion from being heard in its defence, he assumes infallibility. And so far from the assumption being less objectionable or less dangerous because the opinion is called immoral or impious, this is the case of all others in which it is most fatal. These are exactly the occasions on which the men of one generation commit those dreadful mistakes, which excite the astonishment and horror of posterity. It is among such that we find the instances memorable in history, when the arm of the law has been employed to root out the best men and the noblest doctrines; with deplorable success as to the men, though some of the doctrines have survived to be (as if in mockery) invoked, in defence of similar conduct towards those who dissent from
them, or from their received interpretation.
D: Elegant: Take the hardest case: belief in God, the afterlife, fundamental morality. If anything deserves protection from challenge, these do. And yet these are exactly the cases where censorship has done the most catastrophic damage -- destroying the best people while their ideas survived to be cited, with grim irony, by the next generation's censors.
D: Summary: Even beliefs considered most sacred -- God, morality, the afterlife -- must not be shielded from challenge. It is precisely in these high-stakes cases that the assumption of infallibility has historically produced the worst atrocities.
D: Distilled: The more sacred a belief is considered, the more catastrophic the consequences of forbidding anyone to question it.
Notes:
[Choosing the hardest case] -- Mill's rhetorical strategy of steel-manning: testing his principle against the strongest counterexample.
[Infallibility distinguished from certainty] -- Mill carefully separates strong personal conviction (acceptable) from imposing that conviction on others by silencing dissent (unacceptable).
[Historical persecutions] -- Mill sets up the examples that follow: Socrates (2.12), Jesus (2.13), and Marcus Aurelius (2.14).
[Ironic survival of persecuted doctrines] -- The pattern where suppressed ideas survive and are later used to justify suppressing new dissenters -- a recurring dynamic in religious history.

D: Refashioned:
We cannot be reminded often enough of Socrates. Here was a man acknowledged by those who knew him best as the most virtuous person of an age rich in extraordinary individuals. He is the source of virtually all subsequent Western moral philosophy -- Plato's idealism and Aristotle's practical ethics both flow from him. His reputation, still growing after more than two thousand years, all but outweighs every other name associated with Athens.

This man was executed by his own city, after a legal trial, on charges of impiety and corrupting the young. The accusers claimed he rejected the gods recognized by the state -- or believed in no gods at all. The tribunal, by every indication, found him guilty in good faith. They condemned the person who had quite possibly done more good for humanity than anyone then alive, sentencing him to death as a common criminal.
D: Original:
Mankind can hardly be too often reminded, that there was once a man named Socrates, between whom and the legal authorities and public opinion of his time, there took place a memorable collision. Born in an age and country abounding in individual greatness, this man has been handed down to us by those who best knew both him and the age, as the most virtuous man in it; while
we know him as the head and prototype of all subsequent teachers of virtue, the source equally of the lofty inspiration of Plato and the judicious utilitarianism of Aristotle,
“i maëstri di color che sanno,” the two headsprings of ethical as of all other philosophy. This acknowledged master of all the eminent thinkers who have since lived—whose fame, still growing after more than two thousand years, all but outweighs the whole remainder of the names which make his native city illustrious—was put to death by his countrymen, after a judicial conviction, for impiety and immorality. Impiety, in denying the gods recognised by the State; indeed his accuser asserted (see the
Apologia) that he believed in no gods at all. Immorality, in being, by his doctrines and instructions, a “corrupter of youth.” Of these charges the tribunal, there is every ground for believing, honestly found him guilty, and condemned the man who probably of all then born had deserved best of mankind, to be put to death as a criminal.
D: Elegant: Socrates -- the most virtuous man of his age, the source of Western moral philosophy, whose fame after two millennia eclipses his entire city -- was executed by that city after a lawful trial for impiety and corrupting youth. The tribunal acted in good faith. They killed the best man alive and believed they were doing right.
D: Summary: Socrates, widely regarded as the most virtuous man of his era and the founder of Western moral philosophy, was legally tried and executed for impiety and corruption of youth by a tribunal that sincerely believed it was acting justly.
D: Distilled: Athens executed Socrates in good faith -- a reminder that sincere moral conviction and catastrophic moral error are entirely compatible.
Notes:
[Trial and execution of Socrates] (399 BCE) -- Socrates was tried before an Athenian jury of 501 citizens on charges of asebeia (impiety) and corrupting the youth. Found guilty by a margin of approximately 280-221, he was sentenced to death by hemlock.
[Plato's Apology] -- Mill references this directly ("see the Apologia"), Plato's account of Socrates' defense speech at trial.
["i maestri di color che sanno"] -- Italian, from Dante's Inferno (Canto IV, line 131): "the masters of those who know," referring to Aristotle, with Socrates and Plato nearby in the circle of virtuous pagans in Limbo.
[Plato] (c. 428-348 BCE) -- Student of Socrates, founder of the Academy, whose dialogues preserved and developed Socratic thought.
[Aristotle] (384-322 BCE) -- Student of Plato, whose ethical and political philosophy Mill characterizes as "judicious utilitarianism."
[Charges against Socrates] -- Impiety (not recognizing the gods of the state) and corruption of youth through his teaching method of relentless questioning.

D: Refashioned:
The only other case of judicial destruction that does not pale next to Socrates is the crucifixion of Jesus. A man whose moral example left such an impression on those who witnessed his life that eighteen centuries later, much of the world reveres him as God incarnate -- was executed as a blasphemer. His contemporaries did not merely fail to recognize their benefactor. They classified him as the precise opposite of what he was and punished him accordingly.

But here is what most people get wrong about these events: the men who condemned Jesus were not unusually wicked. They were ordinary people with the standard religious and patriotic feelings of their time -- the kind of respectable, conscientious citizens who in any era, including ours, live blameless and honored lives. The high priest who tore his garments at what he genuinely perceived as the blackest blasphemy was almost certainly as sincere in his horror as any devout person today is in their moral convictions. Most people who now recoil at his actions would, had they been born into his world, have done exactly the same thing.

Christians tempted to believe the first persecutors must have been worse people than themselves should remember that one of those persecutors was Saint Paul.
D: Original: To pass from this to the only other instance of judicial iniquity, the mention of which, after the condemnation of Socrates, would not be an anti-climax: the event which took place on Calvary rather more than eighteen hundred years ago. The man who left on the memory of those who witnessed his life and conversation, such an impression of his moral grandeur, that eighteen subsequent centuries have done homage to him as the Almighty in person, was ignominiously put to death, as what? As a blasphemer. Men did not merely mistake their benefactor; they mistook him for the exact contrary of what he was, and treated him as that prodigy of impiety, which they themselves are now held to be, for their treatment of him. The feelings with which mankind now regard these lamentable transactions, especially the later of the two, render them extremely unjust in their judgment of the unhappy actors. These were, to all appearance, not bad men—not worse than men most commonly are, but rather the contrary; men who possessed in a full, or somewhat more than a full measure, the religious, moral, and patriotic feelings of their time and people: the very kind of men who, in all times, our own included, have every chance of passing through life blameless and respected. The high-priest who rent his garments when the words were pronounced, which, according to all the ideas of his country, constituted the blackest guilt, was in all probability quite as sincere in his horror and indignation, as the generality of respectable and pious men now are in the religious and moral sentiments they profess; and most of those who now shudder at his conduct, if they had lived in his time, and been born Jews, would have acted precisely as he did. Orthodox Christians who are tempted to think that those who stoned to death the first martyrs must have been worse men than they themselves are, ought to remember that one of those persecutors was Saint Paul.
D: Elegant: Jesus was executed as a blasphemer by men who were not villains but ordinary, respectable citizens acting on sincere conviction. The high priest's horror was as genuine as any modern believer's. Most who condemn him now would have acted identically in his place. And one of those early persecutors was Saint Paul.
D: Summary: The crucifixion of Jesus was carried out by ordinary, sincere people acting on their deepest convictions -- not by exceptional villains. This demonstrates that moral catastrophe can flow from honest belief, and that those who condemn past persecutors would likely have joined them.
D: Distilled: The men who crucified Jesus were not monsters -- they were sincere, respectable people acting on deeply held beliefs, which is exactly the point.
Notes:
[Crucifixion of Jesus] (c. 30-33 CE) -- Execution under Roman authority in Jerusalem, following Jewish religious authorities' charge of blasphemy.
[The high priest who rent his garments] -- Caiaphas, high priest of Jerusalem, who according to the Gospels (Matthew 26:65) tore his robes upon hearing what he considered blasphemy during Jesus' trial before the Sanhedrin.
[Saint Paul as persecutor] -- Paul of Tarsus (c. 5-64 CE), before his conversion on the road to Damascus, actively persecuted early Christians, approving of the stoning of Stephen (Acts 7:58-8:1). Mill's point: even the greatest Christian apostle began as a sincere persecutor.
[First martyrs -- stoning of Stephen] (c. 34 CE) -- Stephen, considered the first Christian martyr, was stoned to death for blasphemy (Acts 7).
[Moral psychology of persecution] -- Mill's argument that persecutors are typically ordinary people, not exceptional villains -- anticipating Hannah Arendt's concept of the "banality of evil" (1963).

D: Refashioned:
Now consider the most striking case of all -- where the error is measured by the wisdom and virtue of the person who commits it.

Marcus Aurelius was the absolute ruler of the civilized world, and by all accounts one of the finest human beings ever to hold power. A Stoic philosopher whose personal writings remain among the highest achievements of ancient ethical thought, he governed with unblemished justice and, despite his austere training, remarkable compassion. His moral vision was so close to Christianity's that he could fairly be called a better Christian -- in every sense except the doctrinal one -- than almost any Christian sovereign who followed him.

And yet Marcus Aurelius persecuted Christians. He saw Roman society as fragile, held together by traditional religious bonds. Christianity openly aimed to dissolve those bonds. Unless he was prepared to adopt the new religion himself -- and its theological claims struck him as incredible -- he felt duty-bound to suppress it. His reasoning was identical to the reasoning used by every subsequent defender of religious persecution: this doctrine threatens the social fabric, and as ruler, I must protect it.

This is one of history's great tragedies. Had Christianity become the state religion under Marcus Aurelius rather than Constantine, its character might have been profoundly different. But it would be dishonest to deny that every argument ever used to justify punishing anti-Christian speech was equally available to Marcus Aurelius for punishing Christianity itself.

Unless you believe you are wiser and more virtuous than Marcus Aurelius -- more intellectually honest, more devoted to truth -- you should not assume the right to suppress opinions you find dangerous. He made that assumption, and history judged him wrong.
D: Original: Let us add one more example, the most striking of all, if the impressiveness of an error is measured by the wisdom and virtue of him who falls into it. If ever any one, possessed of power, had grounds for thinking himself the best and most enlightened among his cotemporaries, it was the Emperor Marcus Aurelius. Absolute monarch of the whole civilized world, he preserved through life not only the most unblemished justice, but what was less to be expected from his Stoical breeding, the tenderest heart. The few failings which are attributed to him, were all on the side of indulgence: while his writings, the highest ethical product of the ancient mind, differ scarcely perceptibly, if they differ at all, from the most characteristic teachings of Christ. This man, a better Christian in all but the dogmatic sense of the word, than almost any of the ostensibly Christian sovereigns who have since reigned, persecuted Christianity. Placed at the summit of all the previous attainments of humanity, with an open, unfettered intellect, and a character which led him of himself to embody in his moral writings the Christian ideal, he yet failed to see that Christianity was to be a good and not an evil to the world, with his duties to which he was so deeply penetrated. Existing society he knew to be in a deplorable state. But such as it was, he saw, or thought he saw, that it was held together, and prevented from being worse, by belief and reverence of the received divinities. As a ruler of mankind, he deemed it his duty not to suffer society to fall in pieces; and saw not how, if its existing ties were removed, any others could be formed which could again knit it together. The new religion openly aimed at dissolving these ties: unless, therefore, it was his duty to adopt that religion, it seemed to be his duty to put it down. Inasmuch then as the theology of Christianity did not appear to him true or of divine origin; inasmuch as this strange history of a crucified God was not credible to him, and a system which purported to rest entirely upon a foundation to him so wholly unbelievable, could not be foreseen by him to be that renovating agency which, after all abatements, it has in fact proved to be; the gentlest and most amiable of philosophers and rulers, under a solemn sense of duty, authorized the persecution of Christianity. To my mind this is one of the most tragical facts in all history. It is a bitter thought, how different a thing the Christianity of the world might have been, if the Christian faith had been adopted as the religion of the empire under the auspices of Marcus Aurelius instead of those of Constantine. But it would be equally unjust to him and false to truth, to deny, that no one plea which can be urged for punishing anti-Christian teaching, was wanting to Marcus Aurelius for punishing, as he did, the propagation of Christianity. No Christian more firmly believes that Atheism is false, and tends to the dissolution of society, than Marcus Aurelius believed the same things of Christianity; he who, of all men then living, might have been thought the most capable of appreciating it. Unless any one who approves of punishment for the promulgation of opinions, flatters himself that he is a wiser and better man than Marcus Aurelius—more deeply versed in the wisdom of his time, more elevated in his intellect above it—more earnest in his search for truth, or more single-minded in his devotion to it when found;—let him abstain from that assumption of the joint infallibility of himself and the multitude, which the great Antoninus made with so unfortunate a result.
D: Elegant: Marcus Aurelius -- philosopher-emperor, the most virtuous ruler of the ancient world, a better Christian in practice than almost any Christian king -- persecuted Christianity with the same logic every censor uses: this belief threatens society. Unless you are prepared to claim you are wiser and better than Marcus Aurelius, do not assume the right to silence what you find dangerous.
D: Summary: Marcus Aurelius, perhaps the wisest and most virtuous ruler in history, persecuted Christianity using the identical logic all censors use. Unless one claims to surpass his wisdom and moral character, one cannot claim the right to suppress dangerous opinions.
D: Distilled: If Marcus Aurelius -- the wisest and most virtuous ruler of the ancient world -- could be catastrophically wrong about which beliefs to suppress, so can you.
Notes:
[Marcus Aurelius] (121-180 CE) -- Roman Emperor (161-180 CE) and Stoic philosopher, author of the Meditations, considered one of the "Five Good Emperors."
[Meditations] -- Marcus Aurelius' private philosophical journal, written in Greek, containing Stoic reflections on duty, virtue, and mortality.
[Persecution of Christians under Marcus Aurelius] -- Christians were persecuted during his reign, most notably the martyrdoms at Lyon and Vienne in 177 CE, though the extent of Marcus Aurelius' personal involvement is debated by historians.
[Constantine] (c. 272-337 CE) -- First Roman Emperor to convert to Christianity, issued the Edict of Milan (313 CE) legalizing Christian worship, convened the Council of Nicaea (325 CE).
[Stoicism and Christianity] -- Mill notes the deep ethical parallels between Stoic and Christian moral teaching, which modern scholarship has extensively documented.
[The Antoninus] -- Mill refers to Marcus Aurelius by his dynastic name (Marcus Aurelius Antoninus), connecting him to the Antonine dynasty.

D: Refashioned:
Faced with the Marcus Aurelius problem, some defenders of religious censorship accept the implication. They argue, following Samuel Johnson, that persecution is a legitimate trial that truth must pass through -- and that truth always survives. Legal penalties, they claim, are ultimately powerless against true ideas, though usefully effective against dangerous errors.

This argument deserves serious examination, because it concedes the key point -- that persecution of ideas is sometimes directed at truth -- while claiming this does not matter because truth is indestructible.
D: Original: Aware of the impossibility of defending the use of punishment for restraining irreligious opinions, by any argument which will not justify Marcus Antoninus, the enemies of religious freedom, when hard pressed, occasionally accept this consequence, and say, with Dr. Johnson, that the persecutors of Christianity were in the right; that persecution is an ordeal through which truth ought to pass, and always passes successfully, legal penalties being, in the end, powerless against truth, though sometimes beneficially effective against mischievous errors. This is a form of the argument for religious intolerance, sufficiently remarkable not to be passed without notice.
