Its ideal of character is to have no marked character at all -- to compress every part of human nature that stands out, the way foot-binding deforms what grows naturally, until the person conforms to the smooth outline of the ordinary.
D: Original: There is one characteristic of the present direction of public opinion, peculiarly calculated to make it intolerant of any marked demonstration of individuality. The general average of mankind are not only moderate in intellect, but also moderate in inclinations: they have no tastes or wishes strong enough to incline them to do anything unusual, and they consequently do not understand those who have, and class all such with the wild and intemperate whom they are accustomed to look down upon. Now, in addition to this fact which is general, we have only to suppose that a strong movement has set in towards the improvement of morals, and it is evident what we have to expect. In these days such a movement has set in; much has actually been effected in the way of increased regularity of conduct, and discouragement of excesses; and there is a philanthropic spirit abroad, for the exercise of which there is no more inviting field than the moral and prudential improvement of our fellow-creatures. These tendencies of the times cause the public to be more disposed than at most former periods to prescribe general rules of conduct, and endeavour to make every one conform to the approved standard. And that standard, express or tacit, is to desire nothing strongly. Its ideal of character is to be without any marked character; to maim by compression, like a Chinese lady’s foot, every part of human nature which stands out prominently, and tends to make the person markedly dissimilar in outline to commonplace humanity.
D: Elegant: Most people are moderate in both intellect and desire. Having no strong wishes of their own, they cannot understand those who do, and class them with the reckless. Add a social movement devoted to moral improvement -- always eager to reform others -- and the pressure to conform becomes overwhelming. The reigning standard is to want nothing strongly. Its ideal is to have no marked character at all -- to compress every natural prominence until the person fits the smooth, featureless outline of the ordinary.
D: Summary: Most people, moderate in both intellect and desire, cannot understand those with strong inclinations and categorize them as reckless. Combined with philanthropic movements aimed at moral improvement, this produces intense pressure to conform. The prevailing ideal is to have no strong desires and no distinctive character.
D: Distilled: The prevailing ideal is to desire nothing strongly and to have no marked character -- to compress every human prominence into featureless conformity.
Notes: Chinese lady's foot -- Mill references the practice of foot-binding in China, which involved breaking and tightly wrapping young girls' feet to prevent growth, practiced from roughly the 10th century through the early 20th century. Mill uses it as a metaphor for the deliberate deformation of human nature through enforced conformity. The 'philanthropic spirit abroad' refers to the Victorian moral reform movements of the 1840s-1850s, including temperance campaigns, Sabbatarian movements, and various societies for the suppression of vice.

D: Refashioned:
Like all ideals that exclude half of what is desirable, this one produces a poor imitation of what remains. Instead of strong energy guided by reason and deep feeling governed by will, the result is weakness that conforms without requiring will or reason at all.

Energetic character on any meaningful scale is becoming a relic. The only real outlet for energy is career. Whatever remains goes into hobbies -- useful perhaps, but always narrow. Our greatness is entirely collective; individually, we are small. But our nations were not built by such people, and people of a different stamp will be needed to prevent their decline.
D: Original: As is usually the case with ideals which exclude one-half of what is desirable, the present standard of approbation produces only an inferior imitation of the other half. Instead of great energies guided by vigorous reason, and strong feelings strongly controlled by a conscientious will, its result is weak feelings and weak energies, which therefore can be kept in outward conformity to rule without any strength either of will or of reason. Already energetic characters on any large scale are becoming merely traditional. There is now scarcely any outlet for energy in this country except business. The energy expended in this may still be regarded as considerable. What little is left from that employment, is expended on some hobby; which may be a useful, even a philanthropic hobby, but is always some one thing, and generally a thing of small dimensions. The greatness of England is now all collective: individually small, we only appear capable of anything great by our habit of combining; and with this our moral and religious philanthropists are perfectly contented. But it was men of another stamp than this that made England what it has been; and men of another stamp will be needed to prevent its decline.
D: Elegant: An ideal that excludes half of what is desirable produces a poor imitation of the remaining half. Instead of great energy guided by reason and strong feelings governed by will, we get weak energy and weak feeling that conform without requiring will at all. Energetic character is becoming a relic. The only outlet for real energy is career. Whatever is left goes into hobbies -- useful perhaps, but always small. Our greatness is entirely collective; individually, we are small. But our nations were not built by such people, and people of a different stamp will be needed to prevent their decline.
D: Summary: The prevailing standard produces weak feelings and weak energies rather than strong feelings under strong self-governance. Energetic character is disappearing; the only outlet for energy is work, with whatever remains directed into small hobbies. National greatness has become purely collective, but collectively-minded people alone cannot sustain it.
D: Distilled: An ideal that demands nothing strongly felt produces nothing strongly done -- our greatness becomes collective because individually we have become small.
Notes: Mill's observation that 'the greatness of England is now all collective' reflects anxieties about industrialization and the rise of large-scale institutions in Victorian Britain. The concern that individual initiative was being replaced by organizational capacity was shared by Carlyle, Arnold, and Ruskin. Mill's argument that national decline follows the loss of individual energy anticipates later historical theories about civilizational cycles, including Oswald Spengler's The Decline of the West (1918-1922).

D: Refashioned:
The tyranny of custom is the permanent obstacle to human progress. It stands in constant opposition to every impulse toward something better -- whether that impulse is called the spirit of liberty, the spirit of progress, or the spirit of improvement.

These spirits are related but not identical. The spirit of improvement sometimes tries to force progress on unwilling people, and the spirit of liberty may temporarily ally with opponents of improvement to resist such coercion. But the only reliable and permanent source of improvement is liberty, because liberty creates as many independent centers of innovation as there are free individuals.

The contest between custom and progress is the central drama of human history. Most of the world, strictly speaking, has no history at all, because custom won completely. Throughout much of Asia and the Middle East, custom became the final authority on everything -- justice, right, conduct. The result is visible. These civilizations were once the most advanced on earth. They invented writing, agriculture, architecture, and governance while the ancestors of modern Europeans wandered in forests. But they stopped progressing. When? When they ceased to possess individuality.

If Europe faces a similar fate, it will take a different form. The threat is not stagnation in the traditional sense. Modern Western societies proscribe uniqueness but embrace change -- so long as everyone changes together. Fashion shifts constantly, but everyone must follow the same fashion. We adopt new technologies but discard them on schedule. We pursue improvement in politics, education, even morals -- though moral improvement mostly means persuading or forcing others to be more like us.

We do not object to progress. We object to individuality. We would consider it an achievement to make everyone alike, forgetting that it is precisely the differences between people that reveal the limitations of any single type and point toward something better.

China stands as the cautionary example. A nation of considerable talent and even wisdom, equipped early on with an excellent set of customs designed by thinkers any civilization would respect, and possessing a sophisticated system for ensuring that the best-educated citizens occupy positions of authority. If any nation had discovered the formula for permanent progress, it was China. Instead, China became static for centuries, and any future improvement would have to come from outside influences.

China succeeded spectacularly at what modern conformist culture is working toward: making everyone think and act by the same rules. And these are the fruits. The modern regime of public opinion is, in disorganized form, what the Chinese system was in organized form. Unless individuality can assert itself against this pressure, the West, despite its heritage, will tend toward the same destination.
D: Original:
The despotism of custom is everywhere the standing hindrance to human advancement, being in unceasing antagonism to that disposition to aim at something better than customary, which is called, according to circumstances, the spirit of liberty, or that of progress or improvement. The spirit of improvement is not always a spirit of liberty, for it may aim at forcing improvements on an unwilling people; and the spirit of liberty, in so far as it resists such attempts, may ally itself locally and temporarily with the opponents of improvement; but the only unfailing and permanent source of improvement is liberty, since by it there are as many possible independent centres of improvement as there are individuals. The progressive principle, however, in either shape, whether as the love of liberty or of improvement, is antagonistic to the sway of Custom, involving at least emancipation from that yoke; and the contest between the two constitutes the chief interest of the history of mankind. The greater part of the world has, properly speaking, no history, because the despotism of Custom is complete. This is the case over the whole East. Custom is there, in all things, the final appeal; justice and right mean conformity to custom; the argument of custom no one, unless some tyrant intoxicated with power, thinks of resisting. And we see the result. Those nations must once have had originality; they did not start out of the ground populous, lettered, and versed in many of the arts of life; they made themselves all this, and were then the greatest and most powerful nations of the world. What are they now? The subjects or dependents of tribes whose forefathers wandered in the forests when theirs had magnificent palaces and gorgeous temples, but over whom custom exercised only a divided rule with liberty and progress. A people, it appears, may be progressive for a certain length of time, and then stop: when does it stop? When it ceases to possess individuality. If a similar change should befall the nations of Europe, it will not be in exactly the same shape: the despotism of custom with which these nations are threatened is not precisely stationariness. It proscribes singularity, but it does not preclude change, provided all change together. We have discarded the fixed costumes of our forefathers; every one must still dress like other people, but the fashion may change once or twice a year. We thus take care that when there is change it shall be for change’s sake, and not from any idea of beauty or convenience; for the same idea of beauty or convenience would not strike all the world at the same moment, and be simultaneously thrown aside by all at another moment. But we are progressive as well as changeable: we continually make new inventions in mechanical things, and keep them until they are again superseded by better; we are eager for improvement in politics, in education, even in morals, though in this last our idea of improvement chiefly consists in persuading or forcing other people to be as good as ourselves. It is not progress that we object to; on the contrary, we flatter ourselves that we are the most progressive people who ever lived. It is individuality that we war against: we should think we had done wonders if we had made ourselves all alike; forgetting that the unlikeness of one person to another is generally the first thing which draws the attention of either to the imperfection of his own type, and the superiority of another, or the possibility, by combining the advantages of both, of producing something better than either. We have a warning example in China—a nation of much talent, and, in some respects, even wisdom, owing to the rare good fortune of having been provided at an early period with a particularly good set of customs, the work, in some measure, of men to whom even the most enlightened European must accord, under certain limitations, the title of sages and philosophers. They are remarkable, too, in the excellence of their apparatus for impressing, as far as possible, the best wisdom they possess upon every mind in the community, and securing that those who have appropriated most of it shall occupy the posts of honour and power. Surely the people who did this have discovered the secret of human progressiveness, and must have kept themselves steadily at the head of the movement of the world. On the contrary, they have become stationary—have remained so for thousands of years; and if they are ever to be farther improved, it must be by foreigners. They have succeeded beyond all hope in what English philanthropists are so industriously working at—in making a people all alike, all governing their thoughts and conduct by the same maxims and rules; and these are the fruits. The modern
régime of public opinion is, in an unorganized form, what the Chinese educational and political systems are in an organized; and unless individuality shall be able successfully to assert itself against this yoke, Europe, notwithstanding its noble antecedents and its professed Christianity, will tend to become another China.
D: Elegant: The tyranny of custom is the standing obstacle to human advancement. The only permanent source of improvement is liberty, because it creates as many independent centers of innovation as there are free individuals. The contest between custom and progress is the central drama of history -- and most of the world has no history because custom won completely. Ancient civilizations that once led the world stopped progressing when they lost individuality. If Europe faces a similar fate, it will look different -- we embrace change, so long as everyone changes together. We do not object to progress; we object to individuality. China is the warning: a nation of genuine talent, equipped with excellent customs and a meritocratic system, that achieved precisely what conformist culture aspires to -- making everyone alike -- and became static for centuries. Modern public opinion is the same system in disorganized form. Unless individuality asserts itself, the West will converge on the same destination.
D: Summary: Custom is the permanent enemy of progress, and liberty is the only reliable source of improvement because it creates independent centers of innovation. Ancient civilizations stagnated when they lost individuality. China, despite its talent and sophisticated institutions, became static by succeeding at making everyone alike. Modern Western public opinion pursues the same goal in disorganized form, risking the same result.
D: Distilled: The only unfailing source of improvement is liberty, because it creates as many independent centers of innovation as there are free individuals.
Notes: China as an example of civilizational stagnation -- Mill's characterization reflects a common 19th-century European view, influenced by Hegel's Philosophy of History (1837), which placed China at an early stage of historical development. Modern historians view this framing as Eurocentric and factually oversimplified; China experienced significant internal change and innovation during periods Mill characterizes as static. The 'particularly good set of customs' refers to Confucian social philosophy, attributed to Confucius (551-479 BC) and his successors, particularly Mencius. The Chinese examination system (keju) for selecting government officials based on merit, operational from 605 to 1905 AD, is what Mill references regarding ensuring 'those who have appropriated most wisdom shall occupy the posts of honour and power.' Regime -- Mill uses the French term to describe the system of public opinion, possibly echoing Tocqueville's terminology. The passage also recalls Humboldt's two conditions for human development: freedom and variety of situations.

D: Refashioned:
What has preserved Europe from the fate of civilizations that stagnated? Not any inherent superiority -- that, where it exists, is an effect, not a cause. What saved Europe was its remarkable diversity. Individuals, classes, and nations were profoundly unlike one another. They pursued radically different paths, each producing something valuable. Although they were often intolerant of one another, their attempts to suppress each other's development rarely succeeded permanently, and each eventually absorbed the good that others had to offer. Europe owes its progressive, many-sided development entirely to this plurality of paths.

But this advantage is eroding. Europe is already moving toward the ideal of making everyone alike. Tocqueville observed that the French of his day resembled one another far more than the previous generation. The same is true of every developed nation to an even greater degree.

Recall Humboldt's two conditions for human development: freedom and variety of circumstances. The second is disappearing rapidly. The conditions that once shaped different classes, regions, and professions into genuinely different worlds are dissolving. People increasingly consume the same media, visit the same places, share the same aspirations, enjoy the same rights, and possess the same means of asserting them. The remaining differences in social position are trivial compared to those that have vanished.

Every major trend accelerates this convergence. Political reform raises the low and lowers the high. Universal education brings everyone under the same influences. Improvements in communication and transportation keep people in constant contact. The expansion of commerce spreads opportunity widely, making ambition universal rather than class-specific. And most powerful of all, the complete dominance of public opinion eliminates every social position from which nonconformity could be safely practiced. As the platforms that once allowed individuals to disregard majority opinion are leveled, there ceases to be any institutional support for dissent -- any power in society with both the independence and the interest to protect unpopular views.
D: Original: What is it that has hitherto preserved Europe from this lot? What has made the European family of nations an improving, instead of a stationary portion of mankind? Not any superior excellence in them, which, when it exists, exists as the effect, not as the cause; but their remarkable diversity of character and culture. Individuals, classes, nations, have been extremely unlike one another: they have struck out a great variety of paths, each leading to something valuable; and although at every period those who travelled in different paths have been intolerant of one another, and each would have thought it an excellent thing if all the rest could have been compelled to travel his road, their attempts to thwart each other’s development have rarely had any permanent success, and each has in time endured to receive the good which the others have offered. Europe is, in my judgment, wholly indebted to this plurality of paths for its progressive and many-sided development. But it already begins to possess this benefit in a considerably less degree. It is decidedly advancing towards the Chinese ideal of making all people alike. M. de Tocqueville, in his last important work, remarks how much more the Frenchmen of the present day resemble one another, than did those even of the last generation. The same remark might be made of Englishmen in a far greater degree. In a passage already quoted from Wilhelm von Humboldt, he points out two things as necessary conditions of human development, because necessary to render people unlike one another; namely, freedom, and variety of situations. The second of these two conditions is in this country every day diminishing. The circumstances which surround different classes and individuals, and shape their characters, are daily becoming more assimilated. Formerly, different ranks, different neighbourhoods, different trades and professions, lived in what might be called different worlds; at present, to a great degree in the same. Comparatively speaking, they now read the same things, listen to the same things, see the same things, go to the same places, have their hopes and fears directed to the same objects, have the same rights and liberties, and the same means of asserting them. Great as are the differences of position which remain, they are nothing to those which have ceased. And the assimilation is still proceeding. All the political changes of the age promote it, since they all tend to raise the low and to lower the high. Every extension of education promotes it, because education brings people under common influences, and gives them access to the general stock of facts and sentiments. Improvements in the means of communication promote it, by bringing the inhabitants of distant places into personal contact, and keeping up a rapid flow of changes of residence between one place and another. The increase of commerce and manufactures promotes it, by diffusing more widely the advantages of easy circumstances, and opening all objects of ambition, even the highest, to general competition, whereby the desire of rising becomes no longer the character of a particular class, but of all classes. A more powerful agency than even all these, in bringing about a general similarity among mankind, is the complete establishment, in this and other free countries, of the ascendancy of public opinion in the State. As the various social eminences which enabled persons entrenched on them to disregard the opinion of the multitude, gradually become levelled; as the very idea of resisting the will of the public, when it is positively known that they have a will, disappears more and more from the minds of practical politicians; there ceases to be any social support for nonconformity—any substantive power in society, which, itself opposed to the ascendancy of numbers, is interested in taking under its protection opinions and tendencies at variance with those of the public.
D: Elegant: What saved Europe from stagnation was not superiority but diversity. Individuals, classes, and nations were profoundly unlike one another, each pursuing different paths toward different things of value. Despite constant mutual intolerance, their attempts to suppress one another rarely succeeded permanently, and each absorbed the good the others produced. Europe owes its progress entirely to this plurality. But the advantage is eroding. Every major trend -- political reform, universal education, mass communication, expanding commerce -- accelerates convergence. Humboldt's second condition for human development was variety of circumstances. That variety is vanishing. And as every elevated position from which nonconformity could be safely practiced is leveled, there ceases to be any institutional support for dissent at all.
D: Summary: Europe's progress resulted from its diversity of individuals, classes, and nations, not from any inherent superiority. But this diversity is rapidly disappearing as political, educational, commercial, and communicative forces drive convergence. Humboldt's two requirements for development were freedom and variety of circumstances -- and variety is vanishing, along with every institutional position from which dissent could be safely practiced.
D: Distilled: Europe's progress was never the product of superiority but of diversity -- and every major modern trend is destroying the variety of circumstances on which that progress depended.
Notes: M. de Tocqueville -- Alexis de Tocqueville (1805-1859), French political thinker. Mill references his last important work, The Old Regime and the Revolution (L'Ancien Regime et la Revolution, 1856), which argued that the French Revolution had paradoxically continued the centralizing tendencies of the monarchy, making French citizens more alike. Mill had been corresponding with Tocqueville and had reviewed Democracy in America for the London and Westminster Review (1835 and 1840). Wilhelm von Humboldt -- Mill returns to Humboldt's two conditions for development (freedom and variety of situations) first cited in passage 3.2. Mill's observation that improvements in communication promote assimilation was prescient; he was writing as railways and the telegraph were transforming British society, creating what he recognized as an early version of mass culture.

D: Refashioned:
All these forces combine into overwhelming pressure against individuality. Its survival depends on whether the thoughtful portion of the public can be brought to value differences -- even differences that are not improvements.

If individuality is to be defended, the time is now, while assimilation is still incomplete. The demand that everyone resemble us grows by what it feeds on. Wait too long, and every deviation will be seen as monstrous and unnatural. People unaccustomed to diversity lose the capacity to even imagine it.
D: Original:
The combination of all these causes forms so great a mass of influences hostile to Individuality, that it is not easy to see how it can stand its ground. It will do so with increasing difficulty, unless the intelligent part of the public can be made to feel its value—to see that it is good there should be differences, even though not for the better, even though, as it may appear to them, some should be for the worse. If the claims of Individuality are ever to be asserted, the time is now, while much is still wanting to complete the enforced assimilation. It is only in the earlier stages that any stand can be successfully made against the encroachment. The demand that all other people shall resemble ourselves, grows by what it feeds on. If resistance waits till life is reduced
nearly to one uniform type, all deviations from that type will come to be considered impious, immoral, even monstrous and contrary to nature. Mankind speedily become unable to conceive diversity, when they have been for some time unaccustomed to see it.
D: Elegant: The forces against individuality are now so massive that its survival depends on one thing: whether the thoughtful portion of the public can be brought to see that differences are valuable even when they are not improvements. If individuality is to be defended, the time is now -- while the assimilation is still incomplete. The demand that everyone resemble us grows by what it feeds on. Wait too long, and the very concept of living differently will become inconceivable.
D: Summary: The combined forces of modern life create overwhelming pressure toward conformity. Individuality must be defended now, while resistance is still possible. The longer uniformity prevails, the more inconceivable diversity becomes, until even imagining a different way of living is beyond people's capacity.
D: Distilled: The demand that everyone resemble ourselves grows by what it feeds on -- wait too long, and the very concept of a different way of living becomes inconceivable.
Notes: Mill's warning about a closing window for defending individuality reflects his broader sense of urgency throughout On Liberty. He saw the mid-19th century as a critical juncture where democratic and industrial forces were powerful enough to enforce conformity but not yet so entrenched as to make resistance futile. The phrase 'grows by what it feeds on' echoes Shakespeare's Twelfth Night (Act 1, Scene 1): 'If music be the food of love, play on; / Give me excess of it, that, surfeiting, / The appetite may sicken, and so die' -- though Mill inverts the idea, suggesting that the appetite for conformity grows rather than sickens with feeding.

D: Refashioned: Where exactly does your sovereignty over your own life end and society's authority begin? How much of what you do belongs to you alone, and how much does the community get a vote on?
D: Original: WHAT, then, is the rightful limit to the sovereignty of the individual over himself? Where does the authority of society begin? How much of human life should be assigned to individuality, and how much to society?
D: Elegant: The defining question of political life is not who rules, but where the border falls between what is mine to decide and what is ours.
D: Summary: Mill poses the chapter's central question: what is the proper boundary between individual freedom and social authority? How do we divide human life between personal sovereignty and collective jurisdiction?
D: Distilled: The fundamental political question is not who holds power, but where the line falls between individual sovereignty and social authority.
Notes: This passage frames the central problem of Chapter 4, which Mill considers the practical application of everything argued in Chapters 2 and 3. The question echoes debates from Locke's Second Treatise (1689) through to contemporary constitutional law.

D: Refashioned: The principle is straightforward: each domain gets jurisdiction over what primarily falls within it. What chiefly affects only you belongs to your individual freedom. What chiefly affects others belongs to society's authority.
D: Original: Each will receive its proper share, if each has that which more particularly concerns it. To individuality should belong the part of life in which it is chiefly the individual that is interested; to society, the part which chiefly interests society.
D: Elegant: Let individuality govern what is chiefly the individual's concern, and society govern what is chiefly society's.
D: Summary: Mill's dividing principle is simple: jurisdiction follows impact. Matters primarily affecting the individual belong to individual freedom; matters primarily affecting others belong to social authority.
D: Distilled: Jurisdiction follows impact: what primarily concerns only you is yours to decide; what primarily concerns others is society's to regulate.
Notes: This formulation anticipates the 'harm principle' as a jurisdictional rule rather than a moral one. The simplicity of the statement belies the difficulty of application, which Mill spends the rest of the chapter working through.

D: Refashioned:
You do not sign a contract to join society, but you do owe something for its protection. Living among others creates two basic obligations: first, do not violate other people's rights; second, bear your fair share of the costs of maintaining the social order. Society can enforce both of these.

Beyond that, your behavior toward others can be hurtful without technically violating anyone's rights. In those cases, you are answerable to social opinion, though not to law. The moment your conduct materially affects other people's interests, society has jurisdiction. The question becomes whether intervening will do more good than harm.

But when your conduct affects no one but yourself -- or affects others only if they voluntarily involve themselves -- there should be complete freedom, both legal and social, to act and to live with the consequences.
D: Original: Though society is not founded on a contract, and though no good purpose is answered by inventing a contract in order to deduce social obligations from it, every one who receives the protection of society owes a return for the benefit, and the fact of living in society renders it indispensable that each should be bound to observe a certain line of conduct towards the rest. This conduct consists first, in not injuring the interests of one another; or rather certain interests, which, either by express legal provision or by tacit understanding, ought to be considered as rights; and secondly, in each person’s bearing his share (to be fixed on some equitable principle) of the labours and sacrifices incurred for defending the society or its members from injury and molestation. These conditions society is justified in enforcing at all costs to those who endeavour to withhold fulfilment. Nor is this all that society may do. The acts of an individual may be hurtful to others, or wanting in due consideration for their welfare, without going the length of violating any of their constituted rights. The offender may then be justly punished by opinion, though not by law. As soon as any part of a person’s conduct affects prejudicially the interests of others, society has jurisdiction over it, and the question whether the general welfare will or will not be promoted by interfering with it, becomes open to discussion. But there is no room for entertaining any such question when a person’s conduct affects the interests of no persons besides himself, or needs not affect them unless they like (all the persons concerned being of full age, and the ordinary amount of understanding). In all such cases there should be perfect freedom, legal and social, to do the action and stand the consequences.
D: Elegant: Society may compel you to respect others' rights and bear your share of common burdens. It may judge you by social opinion when your behavior harms others without breaking laws. But where your conduct touches no one's interests but your own, freedom should be absolute -- legal and social, without exception.
D: Summary: Living in society creates two enforceable obligations: respect others' rights and share the costs of collective defense. Beyond these, conduct affecting others is subject to social opinion. But conduct affecting only yourself demands complete freedom.
D: Distilled: Society may enforce your obligations to others, but where your conduct affects only yourself, freedom should be absolute.
Notes: Mill explicitly rejects social contract theory (Rousseau, Hobbes) while preserving its practical conclusions. The distinction between legal enforcement and social opinion enforcement is central to Mill's framework -- he recognizes both as forms of coercion but calibrates them differently. The parenthetical about 'full age and ordinary understanding' carves out exceptions for children and those with diminished capacity.

D: Refashioned:
This is not a doctrine of selfish indifference. It does not say people should ignore each other's well-being. The opposite: we need far more genuine effort to help each other flourish. But benevolence has better tools than coercion -- persuasion, example, education, honest counsel.

You should absolutely tell someone you think they are making a mistake. You should argue, encourage, even press your case. What you may not do is force them. No one -- no individual, no majority -- is entitled to dictate to a competent adult what they shall do with their own life.

Why? Because you are the world's leading expert on your own circumstances. Society's interest in your private choices is marginal and indirect. When the public overrides your judgment about your own affairs, it acts on generalizations that may not apply to your case, wielded by people who know less about your situation than you do. You remain the final judge. Whatever mistakes you make on your own account are far less dangerous than the evil of letting others compel you toward their idea of your good.
D: Original: It would be a great misunderstanding of this doctrine to suppose that it is one of selfish indifference, which pretends that human beings have no business with each other’s conduct in life, and that they should not concern themselves about the well-doing or well-being of one another, unless their own interest is involved. Instead of any diminution, there is need of a great increase of disinterested exertion to promote the good of others. But disinterested benevolence can find other instruments to persuade people to their good, than whips and scourges, either of the literal or the metaphorical sort. I am the last person to undervalue the self-regarding virtues; they are only second in importance, if even second, to the social. It is equally the business of education to cultivate both. But even education works by conviction and persuasion as well as by compulsion, and it is by the former only that, when the period of education is past, the self-regarding virtues should be inculcated. Human beings owe to each other help to distinguish the better from the worse, and encouragement to choose the former and avoid the latter. They should be for ever stimulating each other to increased exercise of their higher faculties, and increased direction of their feelings and aims towards wise instead of foolish, elevating instead of degrading, objects and contemplations. But neither one person, nor any number of persons, is warranted in saying to another human creature of ripe years, that he shall not do with his life for his own benefit what he chooses to do with it. He is the person most interested in his own well-being: the interest which any other person, except in cases of strong personal attachment, can have in it, is trifling, compared with that which he himself has; the interest which society has in him individually (except as to his conduct to others) is fractional, and altogether indirect: while, with respect to his own feelings and circumstances, the most ordinary man or woman has means of knowledge immeasurably surpassing those that can be possessed by any one else. The interference of society to overrule his judgment and purposes in what only regards himself, must be grounded on general presumptions; which may be altogether wrong, and even if right, are as likely as not to be misapplied to individual cases, by persons no better acquainted with the circumstances of such cases than those are who look at them merely from without. In this department, therefore, of human affairs, Individuality has its proper field of action. In the conduct of human beings towards one another, it is necessary that general rules should for the most part be observed, in order that people may know what they have to expect; but in each person’s own concerns, his individual spontaneity is entitled to free exercise. Considerations to aid his judgment, exhortations to strengthen his will, may be offered to him, even obtruded on him, by others; but he himself is the final judge. All errors which he is likely to commit against advice and warning, are far outweighed by the evil of allowing others to constrain him to what they deem his good.
D: Elegant: Care for others, yes. Persuade them, argue with them, even press your case with urgency. But no one is authorized to dictate to a competent adult how they shall live. You are the foremost authority on your own life. The mistakes you make freely are less dangerous than the tyranny of others compelling you toward their vision of your good.
D: Summary: Mill's principle is not indifference -- it demands more persuasion and honest counsel, not less. But it draws an absolute line: no person or group may force a competent adult to live differently for their own supposed benefit. Each person knows their own circumstances better than any outsider can.
D: Distilled: Persuade, argue, even plead -- but never compel a competent adult in matters that concern only themselves, because no one knows their situation better than they do.
Notes: Mill distinguishes 'self-regarding virtues' (prudence, self-development) from 'social virtues' (duties to others), insisting both matter but only the latter may be enforced. The argument from epistemic superiority -- that individuals know their own circumstances better than outsiders -- is a proto-Hayekian insight about the limits of centralized knowledge, later developed by Friedrich Hayek in 'The Use of Knowledge in Society' (1945).

D: Refashioned:
None of this means you must pretend to admire someone whose life is a mess. If someone wastes their potential, you are free to think less of them. If they are reckless, self-destructive, or tasteless to a degree that repels you, you are free to feel and express that reaction. You can avoid their company. You can warn others about their influence. You can prefer other people over them for opportunities and attention.

These are natural consequences of their choices -- the organic social cost of living badly. They are not punishments deliberately imposed. There is a crucial difference between the world naturally responding to how you live and the world organizing to make you suffer for it.

Someone who is reckless with money, enslaved to short-term pleasures, or chronically unreliable must expect diminished regard from others. That is not injustice. It is simply the natural result of their choices -- and they have no standing to complain about it unless they have separately earned goodwill through their treatment of others.
D: Original: I do not mean that the feelings with which a person is regarded by others, ought not to be in any way affected by his self-regarding qualities or deficiencies. This is neither possible nor desirable. If he is eminent in any of the qualities which conduce to his own good, he is, so far, a proper object of admiration. He is so much the nearer to the ideal perfection of human nature. If he is grossly deficient in those qualities, a sentiment the opposite of admiration will follow. There is a degree of folly, and a degree of what may be called (though the phrase is not unobjectionable) lowness or depravation of taste, which, though it cannot justify doing harm to the person who manifests it, renders him necessarily and properly a subject of distaste, or, in extreme cases, even of contempt: a person could not have the opposite qualities in due strength without entertaining these feelings. Though doing no wrong to any one, a person may so act as to compel us to judge him, and feel to him, as a fool, or as a being of an inferior order: and since this judgment and feeling are a fact which he would prefer to avoid, it is doing him a service to warn him of it beforehand, as of any other disagreeable consequence to which he exposes himself. It would be well, indeed, if this good office were much more freely rendered than the common notions of politeness at present permit, and if one person could honestly point out to another that he thinks him in fault, without being considered unmannerly or presuming. We have a right, also, in various ways, to act upon our unfavourable opinion of any one, not to the oppression of his individuality, but in the exercise of ours. We are not bound, for example, to seek his society; we have a right to avoid it (though not to parade the avoidance), for we have a right to choose the society most acceptable to us. We have a right, and it may be our duty, to caution others against him, if we think his example or conversation likely to have a pernicious effect on those with whom he associates. We may give others a preference over him in optional good offices, except those which tend to his improvement. In these various modes a person may suffer very severe penalties at the hands of others, for faults which directly concern only himself; but he suffers these penalties only in so far as they are the natural, and, as it were, the spontaneous consequences of the faults themselves, not because they are purposely inflicted on him for the sake of punishment. A person who shows rashness, obstinacy, self-conceit—who cannot live within moderate means—who cannot restrain himself from hurtful indulgences—who pursues animal pleasures at the expense of those of feeling and intellect—must expect to be lowered in the opinion of others, and to have a less share of their favourable sentiments; but of this he has no right to complain, unless he has merited their favour by special excellence in his social relations, and has thus established a title to their good offices, which is not affected by his demerits towards himself.
D: Elegant: You are free to admire or disdain, to seek someone's company or avoid it, to warn others or withhold your favor. These are the natural social costs of living as one chooses. The line is between consequences that arise organically and punishments deliberately inflicted. The world may respond to how you live. It may not organize to make you suffer for it.
D: Summary: Others may naturally lose respect for someone who lives badly -- avoiding their company, warning others, preferring others for opportunities. These organic social consequences are legitimate. What is not legitimate is deliberately organizing punishment for purely self-regarding faults.
D: Distilled: The natural social cost of living foolishly is legitimate; the deliberate imposition of punishment for purely personal choices is not.
Notes: Mill carefully distinguishes 'natural consequences' (people organically losing respect) from 'imposed penalties' (society deliberately punishing self-regarding conduct). This distinction between spontaneous social feedback and organized coercion remains central to debates about cancel culture, social media shaming, and the boundaries of legitimate social disapproval.

D: Refashioned:
The distinction I am drawing is this: for conduct that only harms yourself, you should face nothing worse than the natural withdrawal of others' esteem. For conduct that harms others, something entirely different is warranted.

Violating someone's rights, deceiving them, exploiting an unfair advantage, even failing to defend them when you could -- these are genuinely immoral acts deserving moral condemnation and, in serious cases, punishment. And the character traits behind such acts -- cruelty, malice, envy, dishonesty, the compulsion to dominate -- are properly called moral vices.

Self-destructive behavior is categorically different. It may show foolishness or a lack of self-respect, but it is not wicked. It becomes a moral matter only when it breaches a duty to someone else. What we call 'duties to ourselves' -- when they mean anything beyond common sense -- refer to self-respect and self-development. No one is accountable to others for these, because holding people accountable for them does not actually serve humanity's interests.
D: Original:
What I contend for is, that the inconveniences which are strictly inseparable from the unfavourable judgment of others, are the only ones to which a person should ever be subjected for that portion of his conduct and character which concerns his own good, but which does not affect the interests of others in their relations with him. Acts injurious to others require a totally different treatment. Encroachment on their rights; infliction on them of any loss or damage not justified by his own rights; falsehood or duplicity in dealing with them; unfair or ungenerous use of advantages over them; even selfish abstinence from defending them against injury—these are fit objects of moral reprobation, and, in grave cases, of moral retribution and punishment. And not only these acts, but the dispositions which lead to them, are properly immoral, and fit subjects of disapprobation which may rise to abhorrence. Cruelty of disposition; malice and ill-nature; that most anti-social and odious of all passions, envy; dissimulation and insincerity, irascibility on insufficient cause, and resentment disproportioned to the provocation; the love of domineering over others; the desire to engross more than one’s share of advantages (the
Greek, pleonesia of the Greeks); the pride which derives gratification from the abasement of others; the egotism which thinks self and its concerns more important than everything else, and decides all doubtful questions in its own favour;—these are moral vices, and constitute a bad and odious moral character: unlike the self-regarding faults previously mentioned, which are not properly immoralities, and to whatever pitch they may be carried, do not constitute wickedness. They may be proofs of any amount of folly, or want of personal dignity and self-respect; but they are only a subject of moral reprobation when they involve a breach of duty to others, for whose sake the individual is bound to have care for himself. What are called duties to ourselves are not socially obligatory, unless circumstances render them at the same time duties to others. The term duty to oneself, when it means anything more than prudence, means self-respect or self-development; and for none of these is any one accountable to his fellow creatures, because for none of them is it for the good of mankind that he be held accountable to them.
D: Elegant: Cruelty, malice, dishonesty, the lust to dominate -- these are moral vices because they harm others. Self-destruction may be foolish, even pitiful, but it is not wicked. It crosses into immorality only when it breaches a duty to someone else. No one owes the world an account of their self-respect.
D: Summary: Mill draws a sharp line: conduct harming others (rights violations, deception, cruelty) is genuinely immoral and punishable. Self-destructive conduct may be foolish but is not wicked. It becomes a moral matter only when it breaches obligations to others.
D: Distilled: Self-destruction is folly, not wickedness -- it becomes immoral only when it violates a duty owed to others.
Notes: Pleonexia (Greek) -- the desire to have more than one's fair share, a concept from Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics (Book V). Mill's taxonomy of moral vices (cruelty, envy, dishonesty, domination) versus self-regarding faults (foolishness, lack of self-respect) parallels the Stoic distinction between moral and non-moral failings. The concept of 'duties to oneself' traces to Kant's Metaphysics of Morals (1797), which Mill here partly rejects.

D: Refashioned:
This is not a technical distinction. It fundamentally changes how we should feel and act toward someone.

When someone's private choices displease you, you may express your distaste and keep your distance. But you should not set out to make their life worse. They are already paying the price of their mistakes. If someone ruins their life through poor judgment, piling on additional punishment is pointless cruelty. Instead of anger, the proper response is something closer to pity -- perhaps concern, perhaps honest counsel, but never organized hostility. The worst that is justified is leaving them alone.

When someone violates other people's rights, the calculus reverses entirely. The harm falls on others, and society must respond -- deliberately, proportionally, and with the express purpose of deterrence and justice. In this case, we are not merely bystanders with opinions. We are judges obligated to act.
D: Original: The distinction between the loss of consideration which a person may rightly incur by defect of prudence or of personal dignity, and the reprobation which is due to him for an offence against the rights of others, is not a merely nominal distinction. It makes a vast difference both in our feelings and in our conduct towards him, whether he displeases us in things in which we think we have a right to control him, or in things in which we know that we have not. If he displeases us, we may express our distaste, and we may stand aloof from a person as well as from a thing that displeases us; but we shall not therefore feel called on to make his life uncomfortable. We shall reflect that he already bears, or will bear, the whole penalty of his error; if he spoils his life by mismanagement, we shall not, for that reason, desire to spoil it still further: instead of wishing to punish him, we shall rather endeavour to alleviate his punishment, by showing him how he may avoid or cure the evils his conduct tends to bring upon him. He may be to us an object of pity, perhaps of dislike, but not of anger or resentment; we shall not treat him like an enemy of society: the worst we shall think ourselves justified in doing is leaving him to himself, if we do not interfere benevolently by showing interest or concern for him. It is far otherwise if he has infringed the rules necessary for the protection of his fellow-creatures, individually or collectively. The evil consequences of his acts do not then fall on himself, but on others; and society, as the protector of all its members, must retaliate on him; must inflict pain on him for the express purpose of punishment, and must take care that it be sufficiently severe. In the one case, he is an offender at our bar, and we are called on not only to sit in judgment on him, but, in one shape or another, to execute our own sentence: in the other case, it is not our part to inflict any suffering on him, except what may incidentally follow from our using the same liberty in the regulation of our own affairs, which we allow to him in his.
D: Elegant: When someone harms only themselves, the proper response is pity, distance, perhaps honest counsel -- never organized hostility. They already bear the cost of their own errors. But when someone violates the rights of others, society must act with deliberate purpose: to deter, to protect, to deliver justice.
D: Summary: The distinction between self-regarding and other-regarding faults changes everything about the proper response. For self-harming conduct: sympathy, distance, and honest advice. For harm to others: deliberate social and legal consequences, proportionally enforced.
D: Distilled: Someone who harms only themselves deserves pity, not punishment; someone who harms others demands a deliberate response from society.
Notes: Mill's framework here anticipates restorative justice principles -- the idea that punishment should be proportional and purposive, not retaliatory. The distinction between 'natural penalties' and 'imposed penalties' remains a live issue in criminal justice philosophy.

D: Refashioned:
Now for the strongest objection: 'No one is an island. Every act of self-destruction ripples outward. If you wreck your health, your dependents suffer. If you squander your money, your creditors lose. If you let your abilities decay, society loses what you could have contributed. And even if the direct damage stays contained, your bad example corrupts others. So there is no such thing as purely self-regarding conduct.'

This is the most serious challenge to the principle I have laid out, and it deserves a serious answer.
D: Original: The distinction here pointed out between the part of a person’s life which concerns only himself, and that which concerns others, many persons will refuse to admit. How (it may be asked) can any part of the conduct of a member of society be a matter of indifference to the other members? No person is an entirely isolated being; it is impossible for a person to do anything seriously or permanently hurtful to himself, without mischief reaching at least to his near connexions, and often far beyond them. If he injures his property, he does harm to those who directly or indirectly derived support from it, and usually diminishes, by a greater or less amount, the general resources of the community. If he deteriorates his bodily or mental faculties, he not only brings evil upon all who depended on him for any portion of their happiness, but disqualifies himself for rendering the services which he owes to his fellow-creatures generally; perhaps becomes a burthen on their affection or benevolence; and if such conduct were very frequent, hardly any offence that is committed would detract more from the general sum of good. Finally, if by his vices or follies a person does no direct harm to others, he is nevertheless (it may be said) injurious by his example; and ought to be compelled to control himself, for the sake of those whom the sight or knowledge of his conduct might corrupt or mislead.
D: Elegant: The strongest objection: no one is truly isolated. Every act of self-destruction sends ripples outward -- to dependents, creditors, communities. If harm always radiates, can any conduct be purely personal?
D: Summary: Mill presents the strongest counterargument to his principle: since no person is truly isolated, all self-destructive behavior harms others indirectly -- through dependents, lost contributions, and corrupting example. This challenges the very existence of 'purely self-regarding' conduct.
D: Distilled: The most powerful objection to individual liberty is that no act of self-destruction is truly self-contained -- its consequences always radiate outward.
Notes: The objection Mill voices here -- 'no man is an island' -- echoes John Donne's Meditation XVII (1624). This communitarian argument recurs throughout political philosophy, from Aristotle's conception of humans as inherently social beings to modern communitarians like Alasdair MacIntyre and Charles Taylor.

D: Refashioned: The objection continues: 'And if we protect children from their own bad judgment, why not protect adults who are equally incapable of self-governance? If gambling, addiction, laziness, and neglect are as destructive as many crimes, why should law and social opinion not suppress them with equal force? This is not about stifling individuality or blocking experiments in living. These are not new experiments -- they are old failures. Humanity has run these experiments for thousands of years and the results are in. We are simply trying to prevent each generation from walking off the same cliff.'
D: Original: And even (it will be added) if the consequences of misconduct could be confined to the vicious or thoughtless individual, ought society to abandon to their own guidance those who are manifestly unfit for it? If protection against themselves is confessedly due to children and persons under age, is not society equally bound to afford it to persons of mature years who are equally incapable of self-government? If gambling, or drunkenness, or incontinence, or idleness, or uncleanliness, are as injurious to happiness, and as great a hindrance to improvement, as many or most of the acts prohibited by law, why (it may be asked) should not law, so far as is consistent with practicability and social convenience, endeavour to repress these also? And as a supplement to the unavoidable imperfections of law, ought not opinion at least to organize a powerful police against these vices, and visit rigidly with social penalties those who are known to practise them? There is no question here (it may be said) about restricting individuality, or impeding the trial of new and original experiments in living. The only things it is sought to prevent are things which have been tried and condemned from the beginning of the world until now; things which experience has shown not to be useful or suitable to any person’s individuality. There must be some length of time and amount of experience, after which a moral or prudential truth may be regarded as established: and it is merely desired to prevent generation after generation from falling over the same precipice which has been fatal to their predecessors.
D: Elegant: If we protect children from their own folly, why not adults who are equally reckless? These are not bold experiments in living -- they are ancient mistakes with known outcomes. Why let each generation discover the same cliff by falling off it?
D: Summary: The paternalist argument extends: if society protects children, why not reckless adults? Gambling, addiction, and idleness are proven harms, not novel experiments. Society is merely trying to prevent the repetition of ancient and well-documented failures.
D: Distilled: The paternalist asks: if these are not new experiments but old failures with known outcomes, why should society stand by while people repeat them?
Notes: Mill is steelmanning the paternalist position before dismantling it. The argument about 'experiments already tried and condemned' challenges Mill's own language from Chapter 3 about 'experiments in living.' The tension between respecting individual choice and preventing well-documented harm remains central to policy debates about drugs, gambling, and public health.

D: Refashioned:
I grant the premise: self-destructive conduct can genuinely harm others. But the critical question is what exactly we are punishing.

When your private habits cause you to default on a real obligation -- you cannot pay your debts, you cannot support your family, you cannot perform your professional duties -- you are rightly held accountable. But the offense is the broken obligation, not the private behavior. If a parent neglects their children because of a gambling addiction, we condemn the neglect. If they neglected their children because they poured all their resources into a perfectly sensible investment that failed, the moral failure would be identical. The private cause is irrelevant; the breach of duty is what matters.

Similarly, no one should be punished simply for being drunk. But a surgeon should be disciplined for operating while impaired. An air traffic controller should lose their job for showing up intoxicated. The offense is not the drinking -- it is the failure to meet a specific duty to others.

The rule is clean: wherever there is definite harm or definite risk of harm to another person or the public, the matter leaves the domain of liberty and enters the domain of morality and law.
D: Original: I fully admit that the mischief which a person does to himself may seriously affect, both through their sympathies and their interests, those nearly connected with him, and in a minor degree, society at large. When, by conduct of this sort, a person is led to violate a distinct and assignable obligation to any other person or persons, the case is taken out of the self-regarding class, and becomes amenable to moral disapprobation in the proper sense of the term. If, for example, a man, through intemperance or extravagance, becomes unable to pay his debts, or, having undertaken the moral responsibility of a family, becomes from the same cause incapable of supporting or educating them, he is deservedly reprobated, and might be justly punished; but it is for the breach of duty to his family or creditors, not for the extravagance. If the resources which ought to have been devoted to them, had been diverted from them for the most prudent investment, the moral culpability would have been the same. George Barnwell murdered his uncle to get money for his mistress, but if he had done it to set himself up in business, he would equally have been hanged. Again, in the frequent case of a man who causes grief to his family by addiction to bad habits, he deserves reproach for his unkindness or ingratitude; but so he may for cultivating habits not in themselves vicious, if they are painful to those with whom he passes his life, or who from personal ties are dependent on him for their comfort. Whoever fails in the consideration generally due to the interests and feelings of others, not being compelled by some more imperative duty, or justified by allowable self-preference, is a subject of moral disapprobation for that failure, but not for the cause of it, nor for the errors, merely personal to himself, which may have remotely led to it. In like manner, when a person disables himself, by conduct purely self-regarding, from the performance of some definite duty incumbent on him to the public, he is guilty of a social offence. No person ought to be punished simply for being drunk; but a soldier or a policeman should be punished for being drunk on duty. Whenever, in short, there is a definite damage, or a definite risk of damage, either to an individual or to the public, the case is taken out of the province of liberty, and placed in that of morality or law.
D: Elegant: Grant the premise: self-destruction can ripple outward. But we punish the broken obligation, not the private cause. A parent who neglects their children is culpable for the neglect -- whether the cause was addiction, reckless investment, or sheer indifference. A surgeon operating impaired is punished for endangering patients, not for drinking. The breach of duty is the offense; the private behavior behind it is not.
D: Summary: Mill concedes that self-destructive behavior can harm others, but insists the punishable offense is always the breach of duty, never the private behavior itself. A person should not be punished for drinking, but should be punished for failing to meet obligations while impaired.
D: Distilled: Punish the broken obligation, not the private behavior behind it -- the breach of duty is the offense, regardless of its cause.
Notes: George Barnwell -- protagonist of George Lillo's play The London Merchant (1731), who murders his uncle for money. Mill uses this literary example to show that the crime (murder) is the same regardless of motive. The surgeon/controller examples update Mill's original soldier/policeman illustrations. The principle that liability attaches to the breach of duty rather than its underlying cause remains foundational in tort law.

D: Refashioned:
As for the indirect, speculative harm that self-destructive behavior might cause society -- the vague possibility that someone's bad habits will somehow diminish the general welfare -- that cost is one a free society must accept. The alternative is worse.

Besides, society already had its chance. It controlled the entire upbringing of every citizen -- childhood education, cultural norms, social conditioning. If after all that, some people still make poor choices, the answer is not to add coercion on top. It is to do a better job of educating the next generation. A society that fails at education and then resorts to compulsion in private life is admitting its own failure and doubling down on the wrong solution.

And coercion in private matters actively backfires. People with any strength of character will rebel against it on principle. They will do the opposite of what is demanded, ostentatiously, as a badge of independence -- the way the licentiousness of the Restoration era was a direct reaction to Puritan moral tyranny.

Finally, there is the 'bad example' objection -- that self-destructive people corrupt others by their example. But think it through: if the behavior truly leads to ruin, the example includes the ruin. People can see the consequences. A visible cautionary tale does more to deter than any ban.
D: Original:
But with regard to the merely contingent, or, as it may be called, constructive injury which a person causes to society, by conduct which neither violates any specific duty to the public, nor occasions perceptible hurt to any assignable individual except himself; the inconvenience is one which society can afford to bear, for the sake of the greater good of human freedom. If grown persons are to be punished for not taking proper care of themselves, I would rather it were for their own sake, than under pretence of preventing them from impairing their capacity of rendering to society benefits which society does not pretend it has a right to exact. But I cannot consent to argue the point as if society had no means of bringing its weaker members up to its ordinary standard of rational conduct, except waiting till they do something irrational, and then punishing them, legally or morally, for it. Society has had absolute power over them during all the early portion of their existence: it has had the whole period of childhood and nonage in which to try whether it could make them capable of rational conduct in life. The existing generation is master both of the training and the entire circumstances of the generation to come; it cannot indeed make them perfectly wise and good, because it is itself so lamentably deficient in goodness and wisdom; and its best efforts are not always, in individual cases, its most successful ones; but it is perfectly well able to make the rising generation, as a whole, as good as, and a little better than, itself. If society lets any considerable number of its members grow up mere children, incapable of being acted on by rational consideration of distant motives, society has itself to blame for the consequences. Armed not only with all the powers of education, but with the ascendancy which the authority of a received opinion always exercises over the minds who are least fitted to judge for themselves; and aided by the
natural penalties which cannot be prevented from falling on those who incur the distaste or the contempt of those who know them; let not society pretend that it needs, besides all this, the power to issue commands and enforce obedience in the personal concerns of individuals, in which, on all principles of justice and policy, the decision ought to rest with those who are to abide the consequences. Nor is there anything which tends more to discredit and frustrate the better means of influencing conduct, than a resort to the worse. If there be among those whom it is attempted to coerce into prudence or temperance, any of the material of which vigorous and independent characters are made, they will infallibly rebel against the yoke. No such person will ever feel that others have a right to control him in his concerns, such as they have to prevent him from injuring them in theirs; and it easily comes to be considered a mark of spirit and courage to fly in the face of such usurped authority, and do with ostentation the exact opposite of what it enjoins; as in the fashion of grossness which succeeded, in the time of Charles II, to the fanatical moral intolerance of the Puritans. With respect to what is said of the necessity of protecting society from the bad example set to others by the vicious or the self-indulgent; it is true that bad example may have a pernicious effect, especially the example of doing wrong to others with impunity to the wrong-doer. But we are now speaking of conduct which, while it does no wrong to others, is supposed to do great harm to the agent himself: and I do not see how those who believe this, can think otherwise than that the example, on the whole, must be more salutary than hurtful, since, if it displays the misconduct, it displays also the painful or degrading consequences which, if the conduct is justly censured, must be supposed to be in all or most cases attendant on it.
D: Elegant: Society had every citizen's childhood to shape their character. If it failed, the answer is better education, not adult coercion. Compulsion in private life backfires: strong characters rebel on principle, doing the opposite as a badge of independence. And if self-destruction truly leads to ruin, the example includes the ruin -- a visible cautionary tale more powerful than any prohibition.
D: Summary: Indirect harm to society from private conduct is a cost freedom must bear. Society already had its chance through education; resorting to coercion in private life admits failure. Moreover, coercion provokes defiant rebellion, and if self-destructive behavior truly leads to ruin, the visible consequences serve as their own deterrent.
D: Distilled: A society that fails to educate its citizens and then resorts to controlling their private lives is compounding its own failure.
Notes: Charles II and the Restoration (1660) -- Mill references how the moral licentiousness of the Restoration era was a direct backlash against Puritan repression under Cromwell's Commonwealth (1649-1660). This pattern of moral backlash recurs throughout history: the Roaring Twenties following Prohibition, the 1960s counterculture following 1950s conformity. Mill's argument about education versus coercion anticipates modern 'nudge theory' (Thaler and Sunstein, 2008) -- the idea that shaping choice architecture is more effective than prohibition.

D: Refashioned:
But the strongest argument against public interference in private conduct is simpler: the public almost always gets it wrong.

On questions of how people should treat each other, majority opinion has a decent track record -- people can judge what affects them directly. But on questions of how other people should live their private lives, majority opinion is essentially random. At best, it reflects some people's preferences about how others should behave. At worst -- and this is the common case -- the majority simply cannot tolerate anyone living differently from themselves. They experience another person's different lifestyle as a personal attack, the same way a religious zealot feels persecuted by someone else's different worship.

But there is no equivalence between the feeling of a person living their own life and the feeling of someone offended that they are living it. A person's taste, like their opinion or their property, is their own concern.

In theory, you can imagine an enlightened public that only interferes with conduct universally proven harmful. In practice, no such public has ever existed. Real publics do not consult universal experience. They consult their own feelings and call them morality. And they are egged on by philosophers and moralists who teach that right and wrong are simply what we feel them to be -- at which point the public does exactly what you would expect: it makes its own preferences mandatory for everyone.
D: Original: But the strongest of all the arguments against the interference of the public with purely personal conduct, is that when it does interfere, the odds are that it interferes wrongly, and in the wrong place. On questions of social morality, of duty to others, the opinion of the public, that is, of an overruling majority, though often wrong, is likely to be still oftener right; because on such questions they are only required to judge of their own interests; of the manner in which some mode of conduct, if allowed to be practised, would affect themselves. But the opinion of a similar majority, imposed as a law on the minority, on questions of self-regarding conduct, is quite as likely to be wrong as right; for in these cases public opinion means, at the best, some people’s opinion of what is good or bad for other people; while very often it does not even mean that; the public, with the most perfect indifference, passing over the pleasure or convenience of those whose conduct they censure, and considering only their own preference. There are many who consider as an injury to themselves any conduct which they have a distaste for, and resent it as an outrage to their feelings; as a religious bigot, when charged with disregarding the religious feelings of others, has been known to retort that they disregard his feelings, by persisting in their abominable worship or creed. But there is no parity between the feeling of a person for his own opinion, and the feeling of another who is offended at his holding it; no more than between the desire of a thief to take a purse, and the desire of the right owner to keep it. And a person’s taste is as much his own peculiar concern as his opinion or his purse. It is easy for any one to imagine an ideal public, which leaves the freedom and choice of individuals in all uncertain matters undisturbed, and only requires them to abstain from modes of conduct which universal experience has condemned. But where has there been seen a public which set any such limit to its censorship? or when does the public trouble itself about universal experience? In its interferences with personal conduct it is seldom thinking of anything but the enormity of acting or feeling differently from itself; and this standard of judgment, thinly disguised, is held up to mankind as the dictate of religion and philosophy, by nine-tenths of all moralists and speculative writers. These teach that things are right because they are right; because we feel them to be so. They tell us to search in our own minds and hearts for laws of conduct binding on ourselves and on all others. What can the poor public do but apply these instructions, and make their own personal feelings of good and evil, if they are tolerably unanimous in them, obligatory on all the world?
D: Elegant: On matters affecting others, the majority's judgment is passable. On matters of private life, it is essentially a coin flip dressed up as moral authority. Real publics do not consult universal experience -- they consult their own feelings and call them morality. And there is no equivalence between living your own life and being offended that someone else is living theirs.
D: Summary: The strongest argument against public interference in private life is that the public gets it wrong. On social morality, majority opinion is reasonable. On private conduct, it merely reflects the majority's discomfort with difference. The public confuses its own preferences with moral truth, encouraged by moralists who teach that feelings are the foundation of right and wrong.
D: Distilled: The public's judgment on private conduct is just its own discomfort with difference, dressed in the language of morality.
Notes: Mill's argument about moral intuitionism -- the philosophical position that moral truths are known by feeling -- targets thinkers like William Whewell, whose moral philosophy Mill criticized extensively. The analogy between the religious bigot who claims persecution and the thief who wants a purse is one of Mill's most striking rhetorical moves, equating moral offense with mere acquisitiveness. This passage anticipates the modern concept of 'offense creep' -- the tendency for the range of things considered offensive to expand over time.

D: Refashioned: This is not a theoretical problem. The tendency to impose private moral preferences through public power is one of the most universal human impulses, and it is at work right now. I need to show this with concrete examples -- not to catalogue every moral overreach in modern life, which would be a book in itself, but to demonstrate that the principle I am defending addresses real and present dangers.
D: Original: The evil here pointed out is not one which exists only in theory; and it may perhaps be expected that I should specify the instances in which the public of this age and country improperly invests its own preferences with the character of moral laws. I am not writing an essay on the aberrations of existing moral feeling. That is too weighty a subject to be discussed parenthetically, and by way of illustration. Yet examples are necessary, to show that the principle I maintain is of serious and practical moment, and that I am not endeavouring to erect a barrier against imaginary evils.
